Stocks continue to catch their breath on Monday after posting big gains last week, but Apple (AAPL) made a statement in the stock market today — that the institutional crowd is not yet ready to cash in their large year-to-date gains.X While the Dow Jones industrial average inched barely higher and the Nasdaq composite was fractionally lower with less than half an hour to go, Apple rose more than 0.3% to 149.55, climbing back above the 50-day moving average for the first time since a two-day, 5.3% slide on June 9-12. Shares on Monday got as high as 150.90.The seventh up day in a row for the iPhone and iPad maker suggests that Apple is not only trying to keep its uptrend intact but also may try to form a genuine new base.Apple (72 EPS Rating, 84 RS in Stock Checkup) initially cleared a 118.12 proper entry in a cup-with-handle pattern on Jan. 6-9 and rallied more than 32% before cooling off. The company is into its third quarter of rebounding from a three-quarter slump in both the top and bottom lines.IBD's TAKE: A savvy investor can get an edge in finding new entry points in turnaround stocks and strong companies at the end of a severe market correction by looking for the bottoming base pattern. Check out the one that Apple formed in the spring of 2009 before going on its big stretch run of gains.An aggressive shareholder could opt to buy shares of Apple if it can continue to rally back above the 50- or 10-week moving average with authority, preferably in rising volume. (The 50-day average turnover of Apple is 28.1 million shares.) A more clear-cut entry would be if the stock breaks out to new highs.The S&P 500 was virtually flat, as gains in steel, metal ores, retail, gold and generic drug firms offset declines in the automaker, airfreight, specialty retail, logistics, railroad and movie fields of the market. The Russell 2000 outperformed, up 0.3%.Bob Doll, chief equity strategist at Nuveen Asset Management, notes that low inflation, a U.S. monetary policy that "should remain equity-market friendly," and a global monetary policy that is beginning to normalize all pose as positive factors for equities in the second half of 2017."We think these trends can continue, but also believe investment selectivity is growing more important," Doll wrote in a weekly investment commentary.Indeed, the IBD Mutual Fund index, which tracks some of the best active fund managers on Wall Street, is up 15.8% since Jan. 1, pounding the S&P 500's 9.8% gain so far. See the index and its components by going to the latest IBD Big Picture and clicking on the General Market Indicators page via a link at the bottom of the daily article.Apple is slated to report fiscal Q3 results on Aug. 1 after the close. The Street sees sales rising 6% to $44.92 billion, which would mark the biggest year-over-year increase in seven quarters. Earnings are expected to lift 11% to $1.57 a share.Apple is part of IBD's Telecom sector. As seen in IBD Weekly, Electronics, Chips, Leisure and Building dominate the 33 sector rankings within IBD's stock research tables for mid- to long-term performance. A strong sector helps a high-quality stock succeed in its breakouts.D.R. Horton (DHI) (breakout from a long saucer with handle at 34.64), Home Depot (HD) (saucer-with-handle breakout at 137.42), Nvidia (NVDA) and IPG Photonics (IPGP) are just some of the stocks from these four sectors that are showing unusual strength lately.Nvidia, the top chip-technology player in the video gaming markets, is No. 5 in the IBD 50 and has made big strides in the fields of deep learning, artificial intelligence, data center and self-driving cars. The big-cap tech is now extended after surging off its 10-week moving average near 140 three weeks ago. The stock is also up 35% after bolting out of a 13-week base in heavy turnover in the week ended May 12.Among top-performing new issues, Ichor (ICHR) worked on a fourth straight up day, rising nearly 3% to 22.27. While volume is running sharply below average, the semiconductor equipment firm hoisted itself back above the key 50-day moving average. A new base may be forming, with the correction in the base currently at 35% from head to toe.That 35% correction is typically the maximum amount of decline you'd like to see in a cup-with-handle or double-bottom base, two of the seven principal chart patterns that the biggest stock market winners produce before breaking out to new highs and unleashing strong price runs.Ichor broke the $100 million-revenue barrier on a quarterly basis during the third quarter of 2016, when sales jumped 40% to $105.7 million. Since then, revenue leapt 104% and 103% in the next two quarters while earnings made triple- to quadruple-digit increases.The Street sees Q2 profit exploding 329% higher to 60 cents a share, boosted in part by a 7% decline in the year-ago quarter.RELATED:How Much Will Q2 Earnings Rise For The Top Growth Firms?How To Learn Top Buy And Sell Rules For Growth InvestingThe Latest Names In Stock SpotlightSelling Stocks Like A Pro: What Is A True Cut Of The 50-Day Moving Average?

The country's top-performing stock funds the past three months continued to add a variety of stocks to their portfolios, including techs, telecom, banks, leisure and some retail stocks. Many of these top-rated stocks had strong run-ups, but dipped in June.Managers of leading funds were snatching up tech stocks, such as Nvidia (NVDA), IPG Photonics (IPGP), Paycom Software (PAYC) and Medidata Solutions (MDSO). Chinese tech giants Alibaba (BABA), YY (YY) and NetEase (NTES) were also favored by top-notch funds. A small handful of telecom issues being added include Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) and Lumentum Holdings (LITE).Leading funds continued to ease into select retailers, such as Stamps.com (STMP), Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI), Domino's Pizza (DPZ). IPO Floor & Decor Holdings (FND) shot up to a high of 47 on Jun. 21, but has refunded some of its gains to trade at 39, a gain of 87% from its IPO price as of Thursday.Big banks are in the driver's seat once again. The group started rallying again as all 34 of the nation's biggest banks passed the Fed's annual stress test.IBD found 23 top-notch funds buying Bank of America (BAC), investing an estimated $450 million. The $114 billion Fidelity Contrafund (FCNTX) added shares in its latest reporting period.The Charlotte, N.C.-based firm bank provides financial products and services, serving individual consumers, small and midsize business and large corporations. It offers a full range of banking, investing, asset management and other risk management products and services.Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) (BRKB) announced it will exercise its warrant to buy up to 700 million shares of BofA common stock at $7.14 per share. The warrant was purchased for $5 billion preferred stocks in 2011. Having Warren Buffett as a major shareholder will likely boost investor confidence in the money center bank.Like most banks and financial stocks, BofA soared after the presidential election amid expectations of pro-growth policies and interest rate hikes. After hitting a 52-week high of 25.90 on March 2, the stock has consolidated, etching a cup-shaped base. It's currently building the right side of the base with no handle just yet, but nearing its pivot of 25.90.Morgan Stanley (MS) was another money center bank on top funds' shopping list. It's trading near a 46.08 buy point of handle.The nation's leading funds have been taking profit from a handful of retail restaurants, such as Panera Bread (PNRA), Dave & Buster's (PLAY) and Wingstop (WING). Some financial stocks on the chopping block include MasterCard (MA), Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) and SLM (SLM).RELATED:Which 7 Chinese Stocks Are Top Fund Managers Buying?

A world increasingly focused on microscopic circuits, light-speed communications and biotech drug treatments demands high precision. But makers of equipment able to automate or quantify the processes on which that hyperspeed tapestry depends are in comparatively short supply. That imbalance has sent the stocks collected in IBD's Electronic-Scientific and Measuring industry group collectively up 52% in the 12 months to…

The major indexes rebounded off early-morning lows despite a bullish report in smaller jobless claims last week, yet stocks still traded moderately in the red Thursday. Given the market's strong gains in recent weeks, it would not be a surprise to see the averages finish lower for the week.However, the market continues to show elements of strength as well. The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 major averages are all still well above their rising 50-day moving averages. Watch to see if the Dow Jones industrial average can hold above its 50-day line.The Dow Jones industrial average at 1 p.m. ET shaved its loss further down to just 0.2%. The 30-member blue chip index hit as low as 20,798, just 11 points above its 50-day line.The Nasdaq composite whittled its initial large decline of nearly 0.9% to less than 0.5% while the S&P 500 was off 0.4%. The NYSE composite, down 0.5%, is also facing a fresh test of support at the 50-day moving average. Snap (SNAP), meanwhile, suffered its worst single-day decline since going public March 2 at 17 a share. The stock dropped more than 18% to 18.76 and skidded to as low as 17.59. The stock would now need to rally more than 56% just to match its all-time high of 29.44.The 18% drop represented a $5.4 billion hair cut in market value for Snap, which has 1.157 billion shares outstanding, including Class A, B and C shares.Investors were clearly disappointed by the much bigger than expected net loss of $2.31 a share for the Snapchat social networking site operator, vs. a net loss of 14 cents in the year-ago quarter. Research and development costs ballooned to $805.8 million vs. $28.1 million. A lot of that likely had to do with high stock-based compensation expense, which totaled almost $2 billion for the quarter.Another concern: Snap showed a $155 million drop in operating cash flow. But the company does have $1.43 billion in cash and $1.82 billion in marketable securities, which usually tend to be highly liquid bonds. Elsewhere in the market, Essent Group (ESNT) continued its rebound, rising nearly 2% to 37.30 in light trade. The mortgage insurance firm retook a 36.91 buy point in a shallow double-bottom base.Coherent (COHR), a specialist in industrial-use lasers, also defied the market's decline, rising more than 1.4% to 254.37 in heavy turnover.Other top-rated growth stocks to keep watching for potential entry points include IPG Photonics (IPGP) and Grubhub (GRUB), formerly on IBD Sector Leaders. Grubhub, which enables restaurants to attract more customers by being on the company's popular food service app, edged slightly up to 45.03, extended 6% past a 42.35 buy point in a long double-bottom base.Grubhub, currently No. 26 in the IBD 50, was featured as early as mid-January in IBD's Sector Leaders column, which noted that the software firm's 22% decline from head to toe in a new base was well within the appropriate range for a good cup base or double bottom.IPG gained nearly 1% to 136.73 and volume is running slightly ahead of its normal pace. The stock, which gapped up sharply on May 2 on a strong Q1 report (adjusted earnings up 50%, revenue up 38%), is for now well extended past a 124.37 flat-base entry.Meanwhile, certain retailing stocks got pummeled, reaffirming the problems that some brick and mortar store chains continue to have amid big gains in e-commerce.Macy's (M), which had joined the Leaderboard Short Sales list on March 6 when it crossed back below its 50-day moving average near 31.72, got slammed on Thursday with a 14% drop to 24.99. Volume has already shot well beyond 29 million shares vs. its 50-day average of 5.7 million. The department store chain, which already has plans to close 100 locations, reported a 40% drop in earnings to 24 cents a share, missing views by 31%, as revenue dipped 8% to $5.34 billion.That marked the ninth straight quarter of falling revenue.Luxury furnishings firm RH (RH) and Nordstrom (JWN) also fell hard in the stock market today, losing 8% and 7%, respectively. Unlike Macy's, however, both stocks continue to tread on the north side of their 50-day moving averages.RH, formerly known as Restoration Hardware, has generally been acting well since it cleared a first-stage deep bottoming base pattern with a 39.38 buy point on March 29 in triple average turnover.RELATED:Where Is The Market Headed? X The stock market shed gains and indexes were near session lows in late afternoon trading.The Nasdaq erased a small gain and was down 0.1%. Facebook (FB), one of its largest components, climbed to a new high. Volume was running about one-third more than normal. Volume also was well above average the previous two days, as institutional investors pile up shares of the social media company ahead of its earnings report Wednesday after the close.The S&P 500 fell 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.1% increase. Gains of more than 1% in Visa (V) and Intel (INTC) helped the industrials in today's trading. Volume was tracking higher compared with the same time yesterday.Hospital, building material, truck manufacturing and various retail industry groups led the market. In important stock moves, Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) broke out of a flat base, as shares climbed past the 33.63 buy point. But volume was only moderately above average. The chip foundry is part of a leading industry group that nonetheless has slipped a bit in the ranking of 197 groups. Taiwan Semi remains a group leader, with one of the highest Composite Ratings in the industry.IPG Photonics (IPGP) soared to a new high after the company beat profit estimates. Shares gapped up to a gain of more than 8% in big volume and are now extended from a breakout on April 24. IPG Photonics reported first-quarter earnings of $1.38 a share, up 50%. Sales increased 38% to $285.9 million. It forecast Q2 revenue of $320 million to $340 million and EPS of $1.50 to $1.70, both well above analysts' estimates.The agricultural chemicals industry group came under fire, with a few stocks in that group falling in heavy volume after disappointing earnings reports.Scotts Miracle-Gro (SMG) gapped down to a loss of 5% after the company's Q1 adjusted earnings of $2.78 a share missed Wall Street estimates. Scotts also announced that it agreed to sell its European and Australian consumer operations to Exponent Private Equity in a deal valued at about $250 million. The stock is now dwelling in the lower half of a saucer-type base with a 98.91 buy point.Mosaic (MOS) gapped down and lost nearly 8%, to the lowest level since November. The fertilizer company reported Q1 earnings excluding items of 4 cents a share, down 71% and below expectations. Sales of $1.58 billion were 6% lower than in the year-ago period.That drop extended a streak of year-over-year declines in the top line to seven quarters.Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) plunged more than 8%, sinking to the lows of its current pattern in big volume. The company, which is in IBD's food grains industry group, reported adjusted earnings of 60 cents a share and sales of nearly $15 billion, an increase of 4%.RELATED:Trump Infrastructure Play Soars As Earnings Top On Price HikesWhich Commodities Will Rise This Year? The stock market held strong gains Monday afternoon as the technology sector stood out with several breakouts.The Nasdaq composite, the most weighted with tech stocks among the major indexes, was up 1.2% while the S&P 500 gained 1%.The Dow Jones industrial average also rose 1%. Dow component Home Depot (HD) cleared resistance around 150 and is rising from support at the 50-day moving average. Home improvement rival Lowe's (LOW) topped an 84.10 entry, but the stock dipped below it and volume was light.The small-cap Russell 2000 climbed 1.4%. Although U.S. stocks gains were solid, they didn't match the fervor of European indexes. The London FTSE 100 rallied 2.1%, the German DAX 3.4% and the Paris CAC 40 4.1% as investors applauded the French election results, which left a pro-EU candidate in good shape to win the presidency. The iShares MSCI Eurozone (EZY) ETF jumped 4.7% to the highest level since August 2015.On the main exchanges, volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE.  Winners led losers by 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq and better than 13-to-5 on the NYSE.Banking, travel and some cyclical industry groups led the market. Regional banks, whose shine had been fading for weeks, were among the better-performing stocks in today's market. Western Alliance (WAL), Zions Bancorp (ZION) and Citizens Financial Group (CFG) were up in heavy trading and back to the 50-day line or getting closer to it as they rebound.But it was the technology sector that stood out in terms of chart action, as several names broke out past buy points.Dell Technologies (DVMT) leapt past the 65.88 buy point in more than double its usual volume as shares rose 2.5% to 66.02. The computer hardware company is a member of Leaderboard.IPG Photonics (IPGP) moved above the 124.37 buy point of a flat base. Shares jumped 3.5% to 124.78. Volume was merely average, which invites suspicions about the otherwise bullish move. Earnings for the maker of specialized lasers are due May 2 before the open.A pair of IBD 50 stocks also broke out.Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI) rose past the 52.32 buy point of a cup-with-handle base in heavy trading. Shares soared 4% to 53.78. The maker of semiconductor technologies for optical, wireless and satellite networks tried to breakout out initially last week, but got turned back. Earnings are due Tuesday after the close.Synopsys (SNPS) broke out past the 73.18 buy point of a flat base. Shares rose 1% to 73.63. But volume was about half the usual pace, which made the breakout suspect. The stock has been rising from support at the 50-day moving average.RELATED:Breakout Watch: Top Financial Stock Jumps Back Into Buy Zone

Fiber-optic laser maker IPG Photonics (IPGP) jumped to a record high Wednesday after the company late Tuesday posted Q4 earnings and gave Q1 guidance that beat analyst expectations, with the company citing strong growth in China, Europe, Russia and Japan.IPG stock was up 4% to end regular trading at 121.75 on the stock market today, peaking earlier at 124.27. Shares are now past the 20%-gain level where investors should have locked in at least some profit from the stock's Dec. 8 breakout from a cup-with-handle base at a buy point of 99.08.The Oxford, Mass.-based company, which also has strong roots in Russia and Germany, in its earnings release said its book-to-bill ratio, which measures new orders booked to old orders billed, was more than 1, indicating growth.The company has preannounced its expectations of a Q4 beat. Late Tuesday, it said earnings per share rose 22% from the year-earlier quarter to $1.39, with sales up 25% to $280.1 million, both metrics ahead of Wall Street estimates. Last year marked its first year with more than $1 billion in revenue.IBD'S TAKE: IPG Photonics is not the only stock hitting a new high Wednesday. For the good look at topping stocks ranked by Composite Rating, investors can keep tabs of IBD's New Highs list.For Q1, the top maker of fiber lasers expects EPS of $1.10 to $1.25 on sales of $245 million to $260 million, the EPS midpoint in line with estimates and sales ahead of views.Needham & Co. analyst James Ricchiuti called the Q4 report "stellar" in a research note in which he hiked his price target on IPG stock to 130 from 120, maintaining his buy rating. Benchmark hiked its PT to 125 from 116, while Dougherty & Co. boosted its rating to buy from neutral.IPG says fiber lasers continue to gain market share vs. other lasers such as crystal, solid-state and gas; use less energy; require very little service and are easy to use. They are used in a wide range of industrial applications for cutting, welding and more.In his research report, Ricchiuti said Asia Pacific and China led the way in Q4."Asia Pacific (53% of Q4 revs) increased 32% (year over year) to $147.9M," he wrote. "Sales in China rose 43% to $98M, reflecting strong demand in automotive and for cutting applications from nearly all of IPGP's major (original equipment manufacturers)."RELATED:Why The Needham Aggressive Growth Fund Likes IPG

Stock funds seemed only slightly less frenetic than President Trump setting policy in his first 100 days, as the average domestic stock fund rose 1.83% in January, padding gains of 1.46% in December and 10.81% in 2016.World equity funds did even better in January, advancing 3.86%, according to Lipper Inc.Taxable bond funds rose 0.76%, while municipal bond funds rose 0.46%.The S&P 500 rose 1.90% last month.Not all of the young year's gains are attributable to the new president and new Congress, say stock fund managers and strategists."Regardless of who was elected, the economy was already improving," said Kimberly Scott, lead manager of $2.4 billion Ivy Mid Cap Growth (WMGAX) and co-manager of $288 million Ivy Mid Cap Income Opportunities (IVOAX) funds. "The trajectory of corporate profits had already turned up. The outlook for corporate profits for the end of 2017 into 2018 was already quite strong. The policy changes concerning taxes, repatriation of overseas corporate cash (and) unwinding some onerous regulations that President Trump talked about could boost corporate profits more. But the economy was already getting stronger."And mutual fund professionals expect the uptrend to continue this year."The market could go in two very different ways," said Omar Aguilar, Charles Schwab Investment Management's chief investment officer of equities. "On the one hand, there is a very powerful combination of factors that could translate into record levels for equities."On the other hand, the market could go south. "The attempt at reforms (of taxes, corporate cash repatriation and regulatory burdens) could increase the federal budget deficit," Aguilar said. "There is a potential for trade wars. Emerging markets are still landing. A strong U.S. currency could hurt exports. Those headwinds could backfire into our economy and markets."On balance, Aguilar is guardedly bullish. "On a net basis we will see the market trend up," he said. "But it will be volatile."Scott is favoring stocks in sectors that typically benefit at the outset of a rally. "Many think we're in the midcycle of a recovery," she said. "But we had a significant corporate-profits recession. So to me this feels like an early-stage economic recovery, and that's when you want to shift more asset weight into technology, financials, energy and industry."Consumer discretionary is usually part of that early-stage recovery party. But this time brick-and-mortar retailers are battling digital retailers. Brick-and-mortar retailers are being forced to spend on their own websites and low-cost delivery services, Scott says, which will continue to sap their earnings.Large-cap growth mutual funds' 4.10% gain on average in January led all U.S. diversified stock fund categories.Yet investors were still jittery enough at times to drive precious-metals funds, a defensive category, up 14.94% last month, higher than any other sector. That beat basic-materials funds, which gained 7.31%.Latin American funds paced foreign stock fund categories by tacking on 7.67%.Taxable bonds were led by flexible-income funds 1.61% gain. Treasury funds inched up 0.36%.Trailing precious metals and several other sector fund categories, tech funds notched a 5.13% January gain. IPG Photonics (IPGP) is a technology name that John Barr, manager of $60 million Needham Aggressive Growth (NEAGX) — whose 9.32% average annual gain over the past 10 years topped 96% of its small-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. — likes in a market poised to continue higher but with volatility. The company makes fiber-optic lasers, which can be used for cutting and welding in industrial applications. As costs fall, laser systems become increasingly attractive, especially in welding, Barr says. "Big automotive makers are quite interested in using this for welding," he said.Revenue grew 19% and 17% in the two most recent years. Earnings grew an average of 18% annually from 2014 to 2016. "It has a long runway ahead, with great returns and great management," Barr said.PDF Solutions (PDFS) is another tech name Barr likes. The firm produces software that's the core of electrical testing of newly made semiconductors. It has the potential for taking share from more conventional optical testing systems, Barr says.Two major chipmakers signed on as customers in 2016. PDF's service is delivered on a subscription basis. "So it has high margins and could double company earnings" in the near term, Barr said, especially if it wins customers in China as the Middle Kingdom builds out its own semiconductor manufacturing industry between now and 2020.Ivy's Scott likes MercadoLibre (MELI), an Argentina-based online retailer that offers an electronic payment service. "It's still in an earlier phase of development than Amazon (AMZN) is here," said Scott. "There is no reason to think that demand for online buying and payment will not be as attractive to Latin Americans as it is in the U.S. and Asia."Video-game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) is another of Scott's favorites. The video-game publisher benefits from a console-upgrade cycle and the shift to digital game downloads, which carry higher profit margins, as IBD has reported. Scott says now, "I continue to like the tremendous changes in the products and innovation there. They make games that consumers love. And the way that these products are developed and distributed digitally is such a profit enhancer. We think that story continues."Among financial services stocks, Scott likes regional banks such as First Republic (FRC) and Signature Bank (SBNY), which should benefit from rising rates and from a reduction in their regulatory burden. Trump targeted the Dodd-Frank Act for review on Friday.IBD'S TAKE: Midsize regional banks have gotten a boost from congressional moves to raise the threshold of the Dodd-Frank Act's systemic risk designation. The existing rule applies to banks with at least $50 billion in assets, subjecting them to costly regulations. As IBD recently reported, Congress is looking at raising that to $250 billion.Scott also likes MarketAxess Holdings (MKTX), an electronic bond-trading exchange that claims cheaper transaction costs than traditional investment-bank bond trades, easier odd-lot trading and specialization in corporate credit. "There are others trying to do this, but none has gained the traction that MarketAxess has," she said.Amid the rally in energy stocks, Stephen DeNichilo, co-manager of $2.9 billion Federated Kaufmann Large Cap (KLCAX), likes small-cap Independence Contract Drilling (ICD). The company offers customers of energy exploration and production very sophisticated drilling rigs. "They're on the leading edge of what E&P companies want," DeNichilo said. "They have only 12 working rigs, so essentially they are fully utilized. They have leverage to the U.S. shale-pad drilling rally. They have a clean balance sheet. They are trading below their $10-a-share replacement value. And they could be a takeout candidate."In addition to trading below 10, earnings per share growth has declined at triple-digit paces the past four quarters.Among industrials, DeNichilo likes Dycom Industries (DY). "We like long-term investment themes," DeNichilo said. "Dycom is the largest specialty contractor for fiber-(optic cable). They're the only national specialty contractor that puts fiber into the ground at a time when AT&T (T), CenturyLink (CTL), Charter (CHTR), Verizon (VZ) and other (telecoms) are about to ramp up."That cycle will be sparked, DeNichilo says, by AT&T embarking on a massive plan to lay fiber so the telecom giant can offer customers high-speed internet service. "Their plan is to bring 1-gigabit speed to (at least) 12 million customers by 2019," DeNichilo said. The industry has seen that when dramatically higher speeds are offered at the same or comparable cost, customers switch providers. "Competitors will have to follow," he said. "This will be a big cycle for Dycom. Also, fiber investments could be part of any large infrastructure (upgrade) plan by the government."At the average U.S. broadband speed of about 18 megabits, downloading a two-hour movie takes more than 10 minutes. It takes eight seconds via 1-Gig fiber, according to fastmetrics.com. And AT&T's speed upgrade can be achieved solely through street-side fiber, and will not require any in-home rewiring or cable replacement, DeNichilo says.Dycom's earnings grew an average of 74% annually over the past three years. "Despite earnings growth way above the market, they are trading below the market multiple," DeNichilo said.DeNichilo also likes Martin Marietta Materials (MLM). As the U.S. economy heats up, demand for construction aggregates will grow. "Even without Trump's Mexican wall, nonresidential construction — which is the bulk of aggregate consumption — is still below its 55-year normal level," he said. "This company has essentially doubled earnings per share over the past three years, so its outlook is fantastic whether there is a (federal government) infrastructure plan or not."Ivy's Scott likes water-heater-maker A.O. Smith (AOS). "There isn't a lot of cyclicality in their business," Scott said. "Homeowners have to replace their heaters every 10 to 12 years. And they have a growing business in China for water heaters and water-purification systems. It's a nice growth engine for Smith."Smith's average annual earnings growth rate was 24% from 2014 through 2016. "They're a consistent grower and reliable payer of dividends," Scott added. The company's dividend yield is 1.1%. "We're not a dividend fund, but it's nice to have on top of everything."RELATED: Where Fund Bigwigs Expect To See Stock Gains In 20172017 Personal Finance Action Plan & 2016 Stock Market ReviewClick Here To See A List Of New Buys Of Top Mutual FundsClick Here To See A List Of Latest Sells Of Top Mutual Funds

Stock indexes kept to the upside Friday as the market approached its final hour of trade.The Nasdaq hovered at the 1.4% up level, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average held at 1.6% and 1.7%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today was down on the eve of Presidents Day. The market will be closed Monday.In a jittery market, some selling is natural at week's end. Short-term traders don't want to be caught holding a position that may set up for a whipsaw on news over the next three days. So the gains Friday afternoon were encouraging.Blue chips were mostly up with gainers leading losers by a 6-1 ratio on the Dow.Among widely held stocks, Warren Buffett's  Berkshire Hathaway Class A (BRKA) shares rose 1.6% in volume 39% above average. The stock is 13% off its high.The Street expects Berkshire to deliver 6% earnings growth for the full-year 2015. Berkshire will likely report in late February or early March. For 2016, analysts expect earnings to jump 18%, an upward revision.In the IBD 50, which is a list of the best stocks via fundamentals and technicals, Signature Bank (SBNY) popped almost 4%. Volume, though, was 10% slower than usual.On the downside, fiber optics laser maker IPG Photonics (IPGP) dropped about 7% after offering weak guidance for the first quarter.West Texas Intermediate crude oil jumped 11%, while Brent crude hopped 9%. A drop in the U.S. oil rig count and rumors of OPEC production cuts boosted oil prices.Image provided by Shutterstock.
Stocks fell hard out of the starting gates again Thursday as a global pullback tripped by volatility in China continued. The Nasdaq retreated more than 2%.
The S&P 500 was down 1.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average clocked a 1.4% loss. Volume climbed 28% on the Nasdaq and 16% on the NYSE relative to trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today opened to the Nasdaq dropping 8.5% below its Dec. 2 high and the S&P 500 7.5% off its high from early November. There seemed to be little question regarding the impact of a shutdown on China's mainland markets, pushed past a circuit breaker 7% loss limit after a slide in China's currency triggered a stock sell-off. Markets in Japan and Europe picked up on the skittishness. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended down 2.3%. Europe's top indexes showed losses of 2% to 3% in afternoon trade.

U.S. investors received positive economic news from Challenger, Gray & Christmas, which reported that layoffs by U.S. employers decreased to a 15-year low in December. Weekly unemployment claims data from the labor department was mixed, decreasing vs. the prior week but not as much as forecast by analysts.
On the Dow, only Wal-Mart (WMT) opened higher, rising 1%. Microsoft (MSFT) took the heaviest loss, down nearly 3%.

Macy's (M) jumped 6%. The department store reported late Wednesday its November-December same-store-sales slipped 4.7% year over year. Warm weather cutting into sales of coats, sweaters, boots, hats was a key factor, the company said. Management reduced its 2016 EPS and revenue guidance and announced a series of cost-cutting measures aimed at trimming $400 million from annual costs.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dropped 6% to the bottom of the S&P 500. Yahoo (YHOO) skidded nearly 5% lower.

Finish Line (FINL) flopped 10%, after reporting fiscal Q3 sales and earnings below analyst views and lowering its Q4 sales and earnings guidance. The company acknowledged a long list of operational problems and announced Glenn Lyon will step down as CEO on Feb. 28. Lyon will keep his chairman title through the end of the year.
Among leaders, Constellation Brands (STZ) surged 5% higher after reporting fiscal Q3 revenue and earnings above analyst expectations and raising full-year EPS guidance above consensus views.
Alibaba (BABA) crumbled 5%, putting the stock 9% lower for the week and ending, for now, a bid to retake support at its 200-day moving average.

Fiber optic laser specialist IPG Photonics (IPGP) dived 5% in mild trade. The stock's sixth straight decline put shares down 12% for the week and killed the stock's basing effort.Stocks fell hard out of the starting gates again Thursday as a global pullback tripped by volatility in China continued. This week's IBD 50 list of top-rated growth stocks adds business social network LinkedIn (LNKD) and computer networking company Arista Networks (ANET). Also joining is Paycom Software (PAYC), a cloud-based payroll-and-HR company, and a raft of biotech and medical technology firms.With strong growth, all three also make IBD's tough Sector Leaders screen, where Arista is the new kid on the block. It sports the best EPS Rating and the best three-year sales growth in IBD's 29-company computer networking industry, with the cloud computing trend putting its network switches to work in data centers. Paycom is in the enterprise software industry group. ranked No. 11 out of the 197 groups that IBD tracks. Meanwhile, LinkedIn, also a Leaderboard stock, is sporting double-digit EPS and revenue growth. It's in the No. 1 rated Internet-Content group.Besides these three, five more tech companies clambered onto the IBD 50 this week: biotech Celgene (CELG) and United Therapeutics (UTHR), musculoskeletal implant maker Globus Medical (GMED), robotic surgery system maker Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) and laser manufacturer IPG Photonics (IPGP).Monday's biggest movers out of the new IBD 50 tech stocks were Arista Networks, which gapped up 4% in its fifth-straight trading day of rises, and Celgene, which gave back 2.5% from last week's rally related to resolution of a patent dispute over its blood-cancer blockbuster drug, Revlimid.Of all these stocks, Paycom is up the most so far this year, 46%. Cumulative performance for the IBD 50 itself is a 7% gain so far this year, while the S&P 500 index is about flat for 2015.Follow Donna Howell on Twitter @IBD_DHowell.RELATED: IBD 50 Tech Stocks: Alibaba Added, Web Shopping Jumps.
Stock slipped out of opening gains and into narrow losses early Wednesday. The Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average fell into fractional losses.
The stock market today rolled out in quiet trade, with bond markets and most government offices closed for the Veterans Day holiday.
General Electric (GE) ran at the head of the Dow, up a bit more than 1%.

Security firm ADT (ADT) topped the S&P 500, up almost 7% after beating analysts' third-quarter earnings expectations late Tuesday. Macy's (M) swung to the bottom of the S&P 500 list, down more than 12% after delivering weak Q3 results.

On the IBD 50 list, LGI Homes (LGIH) grabbed a 6% gain in early action. The heavy-volume advance lifted shares to just below an Oct. 21 high, as the stock rebounds from support at its 10-week moving average.

IPG Photonics (IPGP) pressed up 2%, fighting to gain some altitude above its 200-day moving average. The maker of fiber optic laser gear used in test and measurement applications is working on its fourth weekly advance, climbing the right side of a five-month consolidation.

IBD 50 issue Inogen (INGN) dived 4%. The Goleta, Calif.-based manufacturer of oxygen concentrators reported after Tuesday's close an 18% earnings jump, in line with analyst forecasts and a much better than forecast 39% surge in revenue. The stock has faltered at resistance at its 50-day moving average as it works to climb out of a two-month consolidation.

On IBD's Your Weekly Review list, tech consultant Hackett (HCKT) bolted 19% higher after reporting a broad third-quarter beat late Tuesday. The big volume gain left the thinly traded Miami-based company extended above a 15.33 buy point.

Luxoft (LXFT) gapped up to a 6% gain in heavy trade. The custom software developer is extended almost 9% after an Oct. 23 breakout above a flat-base buy point of 68.95. Macy's (M) swung to the bottom of the S&P 500 list, down more than 12% after delivering weak Q3 results.On the IBD 50 list, LGI Homes (LGIH) grabbed a 6% gain in early action. The maker of fiber optic laser gear used in test and measurement applications is working on its fourth weekly advance, climbing the right side of a five-month consolidation.IBD 50 issue Inogen (INGN) dived 4%. The Goleta, Calif.-based manufacturer of oxygen concentrators reported after Tuesday's close an 18% earnings jump, in line with analyst forecasts and a much better than forecast 39% surge in revenue. The stock has faltered at resistance at its 50-day moving average as it works to climb out of a two-month consolidation.On IBD's Your Weekly Review list, tech consultant Hackett (HCKT) bolted 19% higher after reporting a broad third-quarter beat late Tuesday. The big volume gain left the thinly traded Miami-based company extended above a 15.33 buy point.Luxoft (LXFT) gapped up to a 6% gain in heavy trade. The custom software developer is extended almost 9% after an Oct. 23 breakout above a flat-base buy point of 68.95. The Virgin Islands-based company reported solid fiscal second-quarter results late Tuesday.

Tom O'Halloran and Arthur Weise believe their patience is paying off. Mainly, the market is favoring the high-growth stocks they crave. "In 2013 this (strategy) was really rewarded," O'Halloran said. "But in 2014, especially between January and May, these stocks were severely punished. They recovered some of their losses in the second half. Now 2015 appears to be improving relative to 2014."

Managers of $3.6 billion Lord Abbett Developing Growth have seen their fund gain 7.84% this year going into Tuesday. That beat 79% of their small-cap growth stock mutual fund peers tracked by Morningstar Inc., which averaged 6.15%. The S&P 500 was up 3.04%.
That was a far better relative performance than the fund's 16.45% gain over the past 12 months, which topped just 61% of their direct rivals, which averaged 14.84%. The big-cap bogey gained 15.50%.

O'Halloran and Weise look for stock investment ideas among innovative small caps. The managers look for stocks benefiting from six trends: the digital boom, the genomics revolution, U.S. consumerism, the U.S. manufacturing renaissance, the North American energy revival and the rising middle classes of emerging nations.
Tech is the fund's biggest sector. Its 36% weighting is way above the fund's Russell 2000 Growth Index benchmark's 26% weighting.
GrubHub (GRUB) is a digital-boom beneficiary. It's up 45% over the past 12 months.
The fund's No. 2 holding as of March 31 is changing the way food gets delivered by connecting dinners with independent restaurants, the managers say.
Eating Up Sales
Sales of GrubHub hit $254 million in 2014, up from $17 million in 2011. Revenue grew 50% in the most recent quarter. Earnings per share zoomed 50%, 167% and 550% the past three quarters.
"Longer term, the company appears to have a scalable business model, which could lead to higher profitability," O'Halloran said.
IPG Photonics (IPGP) is a leading maker of fiber lasers and amplifiers. The lasers are taking market share from lasers using older technologies. The stock is up 39% over the past 12 months.
"What's particularly interesting is that this company is encouraging new uses of the laser, which are creating new markets that the (older carbon dioxide) lasers never could," Weise said.
One new application is in oil and gas drilling, where the lasers can speed up the drilling of new wells. The military is using it to shoot down missiles, Weise says.
The stock reversed lower Tuesday after Q1 earnings beat estimates but revenue disappointed.
The managers like Epam Systems (EPAM) for delivering high quality software engineers on an outsourced basis.
"The engineers are mainly from Russia and former Soviet Union countries," O'Halloran said.
Cavium Networks (CAVM) benefits from the growth of mobility. Shares are up 55% over the past 12 months, but their Monday close was 11% off their March 23 high.

"When the world becomes more mobile, the amount of data that gets passed around mushrooms. Cavium semiconductor solutions enable more data to move faster and safer in the new cloud environment," O'Halloran said.

Gogo Wireless (GOGO) is giving airplane passengers Internet access.Tom O'Halloran and Arthur Weise believe their patience is paying off. The IBD 50 index wrapped up a strong first quarter last week. The index popped 10.2% versus just a fractional gain for the S&P 500. Let's look back at the list from the first weekend of the quarter for some insight into the outperformance. The Inside the IBD 50 column that week focused on selling pressure in the market and…

It pays to be ahead of the game. Today's Screen of the Day is Bolting RS Lines, which features two top-rated stocks that also happen to be IBD 50 stars. Relative Strength lines compare a company's stock price action against the S&P 500.
Noah Holdings (NOAH) stock closed up 2.4% to 24.51, which means that it has extended past its buy range to 23.45. The stock had recently emerged from a double-bottom base with a 22.33 entry.
Last month, the China-based wealth management service disclosed that Sequoia Capital China had made a strategic investment in its majority-owned subsidiary, EJ Wealth Management.
Noah enjoys an IBD Composite Rating of 96, which means that it has outperformed all other stocks in a variety of technical and fundamental factors, including earnings and revenue growth.
An IBD Finance-Investment Management group member, Noah is second only to Diamond Hill Investment Group (DHIL) .

Cognex (CGNX), which makes vision systems and industrial identification readers to detect manufacturing flaws, has reported hefty double- and triple-digit earnings gains and double-digit revenue advances over the last three quarters.
Sales to its highest-profile customer, Apple (AAPL), make up 14% of annual revenue, a tidbit that it disclosed in its annual 10-K filing.
After a lengthy period of consolidation with a 45.90 buy point that spanned from last July to March, the stock broke out — but it didn't stay in the buy range for long.
Shares closed up 2.2% to 51.58 Monday.

Massachusetts-based Cognex has a 96 Composite Rating and is a member of IBD's Electronics-Scientific Measuring group, joined by IPG Photonics (IPGP) and Faro Technologies (FARO).It pays to be ahead of the game. Major averages turned mixed near midday Tuesday in a volatile session.
The Nasdaq fell 1% early after reports surfaced that a U.S. cargo ship was seized by Iran. A weaker-than-expected reading on consumer confidence didn't help matters.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3%, helped by Merck (MRK), which rose 5% on strong earnings. The S&P 500 added 0.2% and the Nasdaq rose 0.1%. Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges in the stock market today.
The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for April came in at 95.2, well below the consensus estimate of 103.
Apple (AAPL) broke out of a flat base with a 133.70 buy point. It briefly recorded an all-time high of 134.53, then reversed. It was trading down more than 1% in big volume.
Among IBD 50 stocks, 29 were higher and 21 were lower.
Chinese auto website BitAuto (BITA) and Autohome (ATHM), both IBD 50 names, fell more than 5%. Autohome broke out of a cup base Monday, then reversed.

IPG Photonics (IPGP) reported first-quarter earnings beat and were 40% above a year ago. But revenue missed analyst forecasts. Stocks rolled to a choppy open Tuesday, starting mixed, then slipping into moderate losses.
The Nasdaq opened higher, then dropped 1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were down 0.6% each.
Volume was mixed, with trade up 7% on the NYSE and down 27% on the Nasdaq, compared to action at the same time Monday.

The stock market today received mixed economic news, with the Case-Shiller 20-City Composite Home Price Index rising 5% in February. That was up from a 4.6% increase in January and well above consensus projections for a 4.8% gain.
Consumer confidence eased a bit in April. The Conference Board reported that its Consumer Confidence Index slipped to 95.2, down from March's 101.4 and far below forecasts for an uptick to 103.
In stocks, energy plays including BP (BP) and Valero Energy (VLO) were up, industrials such as Cummins (CMI) and Ford (F) were down after their quarterly reports.

Apple (AAPL) shed its premarket gains and slipped a fraction in early trade. The iPhone, iMac and Apple Watch maker reported Q2 sales and earnings well above analyst consensus views. A heavy-volume 1.8% gain on Monday left shares just below a 133.70 flat base buy point.

Appliance maker Whirlpool (WHR) dived more than 6% in early action after its first-quarter sales and earnings both stopped short of consensus estimates. The company said that currency issues and weakened demand in Brazil were key factors. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since February.

On the IBD 50 list, IPG Photonics (IPGP) sparked up more than 3% after its first quarter earnings beat, but revenue missed analyst forecasts. The gain lifted shares to within 4% of a 101.79 buy point in a flat base.

On the downside, China-based asset manager Noah Holdings (NOAH) dropped almost 3% in heavy trade. The stock had reversed sharply off a high on Monday, but its eight-week hold rule remains in effect after its big breakout above a 25.70 buy point early this month.

A mild rebound attempt sputtered Wednesday as the stock market finished with thin losses. Yet a host of technical divergences seemed to contradict the general picture painted by the major stock benchmarks. The Nasdaq composite squandered an early 0.3% gain to end 0.2% lower. The S&P 500 also reversed for a 0.2% loss. Volume cooled on both exchanges. The overall…

The IBD 50 and general market are showing some signs of improvement. Major indexes avoided distribution this week, and a growing number of leaders are setting up in base patterns or follow-on buy areas. LinkedIn (LNKD) moved back above its 50-day moving average Friday as it works on a potential flat-base pattern. Shares have been consolidating gains since gapping sharply…
Stocks bounced out of the three-day holiday weekend, reversing early losses into thin gains on rising oil prices and mixed economic data.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq added 0.1% each. The S&P 500 ticked up 0.2% as a cross-section of industries edged higher.

Early action in the stock market today showed an already stressed uptrend under additional pressure. But volume was soft, and the Nasdaq managed to hold just above its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 rose for a third test of resistance at that line.

Crude oil prices were a key influence on Monday's early trade. Oil prices added to early gains, with the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude up nearly 3% to above $50 per barrel. Europe's Brent crude rose more than 3% to near $57. Currencies were also a factor, with the euro pushing back above 1.10 to the dollar.
While Friday's weak March payrolls report dragged on stocks, Monday's economic news was mixed.
Researcher Markit reported its March service purchasing managers' index rose to 59.2, up from 57.1 in February and above forecasts for 58.4.
The Institute for Supply Management's March service index slipped to 56.5. That was down from 56.9 in February and a shade less than forecasts for 56.7.

In stocks, the Dow was about evenly split, up vs. down, at the open. Its biggest losers were JPMorgan (JPM) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), down 1% apiece. McDonald's (MCD) and Coca-Cola (KO) led the index, up a bit less than 0.5% each.

Barbie maker Mattel (MAT) spiked 6% in early action. B. Riley & Co. upgraded the stock to buy from neutral and boosted the price target to 27.50 from 26. It based its upgrade on new Chief Executive Chris Sinclair and his clear turnaround strategy. Mattel shares remain deep in a 14-month consolidation.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) whirred up 5% after announcing on Friday that deliveries of its luxury battery-powered cars rose 55% in the first quarter, above analyst expectations. The gain positioned the stock for a test of resistance at its 10-week moving average, but still deep in a six-month consolidation.
Most of the IBD 50 list slipped at the starting bell. The worst losses went to Alaska Air Group (ALK) and M/A-Com Technology (MTSI), which dropped 2% each.

On the upside, Cambrex (CBM) sneaked ahead 2% to a new high, adding to last week's 16% gain. Stocks were lower with an hour to go in Friday's session, as investors weighed a raft of mixed economic data.The Nasdaq was down 0.5%, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.3% and the S&P 500 was down 0.2%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume were tracking lower than Thursday's levels.
In economic news, fourth-quarter gross domestic product was revised down to 2.2%, though that was slightly better than forecasts for 2.1%.

Meanwhile, the Chicago-area purchasing managers index for February was weaker than expected, but the University of Michigan's consumer confidence index rose in February and pending home sales climbed more than forecast in January.
Oil producers were the biggest decliners in the stock market today.
Chesapeake Energy (CHK) fell nearly 3% after saying in a regulatory filing that it expects to write down the value of its oil and gas properties in the first quarter due to low oil and gas prices.
Generic-drug maker Lannett (LCI) was down more than 3% but is still extended a little over 5% from a 59.54 buy point in late-stage base. It had been up as much as 10%.
IPG Photonics (IPGP), a maker of fiber-optic lasers, fell 3%. The stock has triggered the eight-week hold rule after rallying more than 20% from an 78.09 buy point in less than three weeks.

On the plus side, Monster Beverage (MNST) led both the IBD 50 and the S&P 500 by soaring 13% to a new high on strong earnings. Quarterly profit surged 64% to 72 cents a share, well ahead of the consensus estimate of 59 cents. Sales rose 12% to $605.6 million.

Tumi Holdings (TUMI) was another bright spot. The maker of business travel gear jumped as much as 7%, clearing a 24.41 flat-base buy point in heavy volume after posting better-than-expected Q4 profit. However, the stock later pared the gain to just 4% and pulled back below the buy point.Stocks were lower with an hour to go in Friday's session, as investors weighed a raft of mixed economic data.The Nasdaq was down 0.5%, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.3% and the S&P 500 was down 0.2%. Stock futures backed away from moderate early gains into mixed trade Friday, tracking Europe's markets after discouraging news reports on Greek debt negotiations.
Dow futures shed early gains and dipped 18.8 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures fell 2.9 points. Nasdaq 100 futures clung to a fractional gain.
The stock market today prepares to wrap up a short, news-packed trading week, with the Nasdaq up 0.6% and the S&P 500 up just a fraction vs. last Friday's close. Five factors to consider:
1. The market's gains in the face of little apparent progress regarding Greece's debt, fighting in Ukraine and the West Coast port strike suggest some investor optimism.

2. The market has advanced despite a week of volatile trading in crude futures, which left the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude trading early Friday nearly 4% below its week-ago settle price, and struggling to hold the $50-per-barrel mark.
3.The market shed distribution days during the week, signaling reduced pressure on the current uptrend.

4. Online travel booking stocks have so far posted a knockout week. Priceline.com (PCLN) led the charge, up 10% through Thursday, putting it ahead 21% so far this month. TripAdvisor (TRIP) has soared 32%.

5. Defensive industries, which tend to rise when investors feel risk averse, seriously underperformed during the past three sessions. The 20 top-gaining industries spanned a large portion of the economy, and two of the top defensive groups, diversified operations and drug stores, were among the 10 weakest industry group performances through Thursday.
Stocks

Some top names including Actavis (ACT) and Avis Budget Group (CAR) were down slightly after reporting quarterly results late Thursday. Deere (DE) also sagged a fraction after delivering its Q4 report early Friday.

IPG Photonics (IPGP) beamed up 4% after comfortably clearing analyst fourth-quarter sales and earnings estimates. The maker of fiber optic lasers and components cleared a flat base in the first week of February and ended Thursday 13% above the 78.09 buy point.

Noodles & Co. (NDLS) was among the hardest hit in premarket trade, down 23% after reporting disappointing Q4 results late Thursday. The fast-casual pasta chain ended Thursday 62% above a September low, after diving 67% over the prior 14 months.

Online auto shopping service TrueCar (TRUE) tumbled 6% before the open. The May new issue turned in EPS of 1 cent and a 38% jump in revenue, both equaling analyst consensus views. The stock has been attempting to climb out of a double-dip consolidation for the past three weeks. It finished Thursday 131% above its May 2014 initial offering price.
Overseas

In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 edged up 0.4%, etching another new high and notching a 2.3% advance for the week. Markets in Shanghai and Hong Kong remained closed for the Lunar New Year celebration. The Hong Kong Exchange reopens Monday.
Europe's markets were again tightly mixed. For the week, Europe's leading indexes were tracking toward slight gains. The CAC-40 in Paris led, trading 1% above last Friday's close.
Economic Calendar

Markets in Shanghai and Hong Kong remained closed for the Lunar New Year celebration. The Hong Kong Exchange reopens Monday.Europe's markets were again tightly mixed. For the week, Europe's leading indexes were tracking toward slight gains. The CAC-40 in Paris led, trading 1% above last Friday's close.Economic CalendarOnly a couple small data items were due out during Friday's session including, at 9:45 a.m. ET, a preliminary February manufacturing estimate from research firm Markit, and the Atlanta Federal Reserve's business inflation expectations survey, at 10 a.m.

Stocks fell mildly Monday as sellers pounced in the final hour. Some leading stocks got dinged in an otherwise quiet session. After snapping a three-week losing streak last week, the S&P; 500 slipped 0.2% after holding a modest gain for much of the session. The benchmark index is less than 1% off its Feb. 25 record high. The Nasdaq wavered…
Earnings season is still chugging along past Presidents Day, with several major drugmakers and technology companies yet to disclose eagerly anticipated results.
Today's IBD 50 roundup takes a peek at two hot biotechs and one laser-focused tech firm reporting this week.

Actavis (ACT) has already offered an early view of results. The Dublin-headquartered specialty pharmaceutical company hyped up Q4 figures last month when it said that its earnings will exceed then-consensus estimates by 10%-15%, led by strong U.S. and international sales growth and FDA approvals of its Alzheimer's drug Namzaric.
Wall Street now anticipates per-share earnings of $3.67, a 16% year-over-year increase, on a 38% jump in revenue to $3.84 billion, when the drugmaker reports on Wednesday.
Q4's EPS advance would mark a sharp slowdown from the past year. Actavis has registered at least 50% earnings growth for the previous five consecutive quarters.

On Friday, Actavis said that it had agreed to divest its Aptalis Pharmaceutical Technologies business to private equity firm TPG for undisclosed terms. The news followed Monday's announcement that it will divest the U.S. rights to the Doryx brand acne treatment to Mayne Pharma for approximately $50 million.

Despite these sell-offs, Actavis has been on a buying spree in recent years. It acquired Irish pharma Warner Chilcott in 2013 and Forest Laboratories last year. And in November, it secured a deal to take over Botox maker Allergan (AGN) for $66 billion after a lengthy bidding war with Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX).
When medicine maker Pharmacyclics (PCYC) also reports after the close on Wednesday, analysts expect a Q4 earnings decline of 7.3% to 76 cents and a 116.5% rise in revenue to $267.5 million.

Shares of the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based biotech shot up 16.4% a day after Pharmacyclics announced preliminary results on Jan. 12. The stock easily retook its 50-day line and has continued to march higher since then.

Management said that the company's Q4 product revenue was around $185 million, above consensus estimates, and predicted that its blood-cancer drug Imbruvica will rake in about $1 billion for 2015. On Jan. 29, the FDA approved the medication for treatment of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia, a type of lymphoma.
A handful of other IBD 50 biotechs also report in the near future, including Valeant and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) on Feb. 24 and Akorn (AKRX) on Feb. 26.
IPG Photonics (IPGP) is no stranger to IBD's "Best Of" lists, with a bolting Relative Strength line worth bragging about.

The maker of fiber-optic lasers and amplifiers also provided a sneak peek at its results. On Feb. 9, it disclosed preliminary Q4 per-share earnings of $1.06-$1.07, above guidance for 86 cents-$1.01, and revenue of $207 million, above prior guidance for $190 million-$205 million.

Those numbers easily surpassed analysts' expectations for EPS of $1.02 on revenue of $203.7 million. IPG Photonics, which has made double-digit earnings advances for three straight quarters, reports full results on Friday.
Its stock found support at the 50-day line in late January and has been on the climb ever since.

Stocks shifted into a higher gear Friday as the Nasdaq scored a new high. The Nasdaq popped 0.7%, while the S&P 500 beat that with a 0.9% gain. The IBD 50 led with a 1.5% surge. Volume rose on both major exchanges compared to Thursday's pace. Friday was a quadruple witching day, which tends to inflate volume. IBD's Market Pulse…
Stocks narrowed losses in light trading near midday Monday following last week's surge.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were down 0.1% each and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%. Volume was light across the board in the stock market today.

Masco (MAS) added 1.5% in heavy trading after reporting Q4 results that topped expectations. The stock gapped higher at the open, but fell off highs. The maker of cabinets, plumbing and other products for home improvement and new construction markets hit a 52-week high and sports a 94 Composite Rating.
Among IBD 50 stocks, Lannett (LCI) and IPG Photonics (IPGP) showed the best gains.
Lannett added 5% in heavy volume, stretching its climb up the right side of a new cup-shaped base. Shares soared 8% Thursday after the generic-drug maker reported solid fourth-quarter results.

IPG Photonics surged more than 3% after reporting preliminary Q4 results Monday morning. It guided earnings and revenue above expectations and will report full results along with Q1 2015 guidance on Feb. 20.
Airlines and chip stocks were the worst performers in the IBD 50, with Alaska Air (ALK) and Skyworks (SWKS) off more than 3% each.

Quality stocks making new highs were scarce Monday, but the new-lows tally also was thin. Several stocks broke out as they leaped to 52-week highs. Toymaker Hasbro (HAS) jumped 3.92 to 59.66 as it cleared a cup-without-handle base. Volume was more than triple its usual pace as the stock rushed past the 59.52 buy point. Hasbro reported quarterly results that…

If recent market action tells us anything, it's that three signs of strength by the Nasdaq — one on Jan. 8, another on Jan. 22 and the other on Feb. 10 — meant something after all. The market's back in a confirmed uptrend, but it doesn't necessarily mean big gains are ahead for 2015. The tone has definitely improved, though,…

Stocks seesawed to a mixed finish Tuesday. Blue chips rose, but the broader indexes took a step back.The Nasdaq ended off its session low, but still lost 0.7% and snapped a four-day win streak. The S&P 500 fell 0.4% to end a five-day run.Helped by a surge in DuPont (DD), the Dow Jones industrial average squeezed out a 0.1% gain. DuPont jumped nearly 8% in reaction to late Monday's news of CEO Ellen Kullman stepping down. According to preliminary data, volume rose across the board in the stock market today.Illumina (ILMN) gapped down and slumped almost 15% after warning on sales late Monday. Intraday, the stock was off as much as 20%.Greatbatch (GB) gapped below its 50-day and slumped 11% on a weak Q3 sales guidance. In a regulatory filing dated Monday, the medical products maker cut its sales guidance for fiscal 2015 to a range of $685 million to $695 million from a prior outlook of $715 million to $730 million. Greatbatch also breached its 200-day moving average.Autobytel (ABTL) ended off its session high, but followed through from Monday's breakout. It added 6% in another busy session. It closed 9% past a 19.66 buy point from a double-bottom base.LGI Homes (LGIH) climbed rising 3.5% to a new high. It is well extended from a 20.20 buy point from a flat base cleared in early August. It's also extended from a rebound off its 10-week moving average.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.
Stock opened the week quietly lower, as oil prices added to last week's gains and earnings reports levied only a modest impact on early trade.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.3% while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq slipped 0.2% each.
The stock market today launched in weak trade, with volume down 27% on the Nasdaq and 19% lower on the NYSE vs. action at the same time Friday.

Airlines were under pressure as oil prices gained. The U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude gained 2% to near $53 a barrel. United Continental (UAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL) and American Airlines (AAL) all fell 4%.

Qualcomm (QCOM) defied expectations and jumped 4% after news reports in China said regulators might fine the company as much as $1.6 billion for antitrust violations. The company has been under investigation since November 2013, according to Bloomberg. The fine would be the largest by Chinese regulators against a foreign operator. Qualcomm shares have been in a deepening correction since July.

Communications device maker Motorola Solutions (MSI) leapt 5% in heavy trade to lead the S&P 500. The move followed a Wall street Journal report citing unnamed sources claiming the company was exploring a possible sale, with Honeywell International (HON) named as a possible buyer. Motorola has been trading flat, within a narrow range for 13 months.

On the IBD 50 list, IPG Photonics (IPGP) popped 3%, pressing further into new highs following its 10% breakout surge last week. The maker of fiber optic lasers and components is now 9% past a flat base buy point of 77.74.
At the low end of the list, Alaska Air (ALK) dropped 3%. The stock has pulled back sharply from January 29 high and is leaning toward a test of its 10-week moving average.

After the close, software security firm Qualys (QLYS), containerboard maker KapStone Paper & Packaging (KS) and China-based online gaming leader NetEase (NTES) are among the companies scheduled to report.

So is Molina Healthcare (MOH), which faces hefty sales and earnings expectations as it rebound from a weak December quarter a year ago. Today's Screen Of The Day is Bolting RS Lines, which includes top-rated companies — such as Silicon Motion Technology (SIMO) — whose stocks are outperforming the general market.

The Relative Strength (RS) line compares a stock's price action against the S&P 500 index. A rising RS Line indicates that a company is leading the market. Today's screen focuses on five highly rated technology companies on the Bolting RS Lines screen.

Silicon Motion Technology makes control and memory components, focusing on NAND flash, a type of memory that has no moving parts and retains data even when the power is turned off. Because it's rugged and small, it's found in smartphones, tablets and a host of other devices.

Silicon Motion stock consolidated from early September to late January. Since then, it's hit a series of fresh all-time highs including Monday, when it rose to 30.50 intraday before closing up 1% at 29.88 on the stock market today.

Cirrus Logic (CRUS) makes a variety of chips including audio and power-management devices and, more recently, LED lighting chips. Like Silicon Motion, it's a smartphone chipmaker. Its fortunes are closely tied to Apple (AAPL). Strong sales of the new flagship Apple iPhone 6 line, which debuted last fall, boosted its Dec.-ended quarterly results.
Cirrus Logic's earnings per share rose 9% to 97 cents, crushing estimates for 76 cents on a 36% surge in revenue to $298.6 million, also above forecasts.
Cirrus Logic shares rose 2.2% to 28.58, a two-year closing high. The stock is up 70% since bottoming on Dec. 2.
Impax Laboratories (IPXL) makes specialty branded and generic drugs, focusing on central nervous system disorders such as multiple sclerosis, epilepsy and Parkinson's disease.
On Jan. 28, Impax received FDA approval for a new oral drug that dissolves in the mouth and treats epilepsy and bipolar disorder.
After emerging from a cup-with-handle base with a 31.14 buy point in late November, it's risen 31% to a 39.24 close Monday, up fractionally for the day. It will report Q4 earnings on Feb. 24.
IPG Photonics (IPGP) is the only fiber optics company on the list. Its fiber optic lasers and amplifiers are used in telecom, medical and measurement equipment, among others.

Its stock, which is also on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, gapped up 4% in more than twice usual volume Monday after it cited preliminary Q4 EPS of $1.06-$1.07, up 52% vs. last year, beating estimates of $1.01. It sees revenue of about $207 million, up 25% and well ahead of consensus for $201.2 million. It's closed higher six sessions in a row.

LinkedIn (LNKD), the top social website for business professionals, burnished its reputation a bit by announcing a partnership with Facebook (FB), which isn't on the list but is far and away the world's largest social network. They jointly announced over the weekend that they're joining forces with various groups to boost the number of women studying engineering and computer science.
LinkedIn exited a cup base with a 232.38 buy point at the end of October and has moved up in stairstep fashion since.

LinkedIn rose 1.5% to a new closing high Monday after gapping up 10.7% Friday on strong Q4 results. By comparison, Facebook shares, after a 1-day pop following earnings in late January, have drifted lower. The stock has lost sight of its 50-day moving average and briefly undercut its new base on Monday, before closing down just 3 cents at 74.44.

Based on a proprietary platform of fiber lasers and amplifiers, IPG greatly expanded the practical application of lasers in a wide range of industries, including plastics and paper. Stocks wavered to a split finish after a round of mixed economic data Tuesday. They also closed the month of August with fat losses.

The Dow and NYSE rose 0.1% each and the S&P 500 edged up a fraction. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq dropped 0.3%. Chip issues stumbled for the second straight session. The Philadelphia semiconductor index lost 1.9%. Deutsche Bank noted slowing demand and downgraded a number of chip equipment makers.
For all of August, the Nasdaq tumbled 6.2%, erasing the bulk of July's gains. The S&P 500 shed 4.7%, Dow 4.3% and NYSE composite 4.2%.
Volume surged across the board from Monday's depressed levels.

Radiant Systems (RADS) reversed opening losses and rallied 7% in more than triple its average volume. The stock has gained 18% since clearing a 15.21 buy point from a handle in a double-bottom base Aug. 6. Radiant makes point-of-sale systems for the hospitality and retail industries. Its sales growth accelerated in recent quarters.

ARM Holdings (ARMH) bucked weakness among chip issues. The stock gapped up and gained 6% to its best levels in more than eight years. It recently tested its 10-week moving average for the first time since its June breakout. ARM makes chips for a number of electronic devices, including Apple's (AAPL) iPhone. Analysts see ARM's earnings jumping 50% this year.

On the downside, IPG Photonics (IPGP) erased early gains and fell nearly 4% in more than twice its average trade. Despite the reversal, the stock still sits 12% past a 19.30 buy point from a cup base. IPG makes lasers for materials processing.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrances (ULTA) also lost nearly 4% in heavy trading. The stock has met resistance at its 50-day line in recent sessions. Ulta's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has dropped to C- from a B+ in late July. The retailer reports Q2 results after Thursday's close. Analysts are expecting a profit of 18 cents a share on sales of $314.9 million.

Stocks improved slightly, but were still stuck in the red in late trading Friday.
The Nasdaq lost 0.4%, while the Dow, NYSE composite and S&P 500 fell 0.2% each. Volume was again tracking lower across the board and has dropped off some more.

American Public Education (APEI) dropped 4% and breached its 50-day moving average ahead of its second-quarter results after the close. The school operator is expected to earn 33 cents a share on sales of $46.4 million.
Earlier Thursday, Lincoln Educational Services (LINC) delivered Q3 profit above views. But the firm cut its full-year outlook for earnings and sales. The stock slid 17% in five times average trade.

On the upside, IPG Photonics (IPGP) erased morning losses and gained 5% to a near two-year high. The stock has rallied 12% since clearing a 19.30 buy point from a cup base Tuesday. IPG makes "fiber laser" tools used for cutting and drilling in the solar, telecom and medical fields. The company's EPS plunged in 2009, but are forecast to rebound 425% to 63 cents this year.

TIM Participacoes (TSU) gapped up and gained 5% to a two-year high. That puts the stock 8% past a 29 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. On Tuesday, the Brazilian telecom firm swung to a quarterly profit of 23 cents a share, reversing a year-ago loss of 3 cents. But that was still 6 cents below views. Revenue lifted 16%, a third straight quarter of double-digit growth.

MercadoLibre (MELI) erased earlier large losses and climbed 1% in heavy turnover. The Latin e-commerce firm fell as much as 7% intraday, despite reporting robust Q2 results. The Nasdaq composite rose nearly 0.6%, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.1%. The NYSE composite lost 0.2%. Volume fell across the board, according to preliminary data.

After hours, Deckers Outdoor (DECK) jumped as it reported Q4 EPS and sales that crushed forecasts. The Ugg boots maker cleared an 87.98 buy point on Feb. 17 in fast trade, but in recent sessions had slipped below that trigger. Deckers, which also makes Teva sandals and Simple shoes, was ranked No. 8 in this week's IBD 50.

Ancestry.com (ACOM) also was up in after-hours action as it posted Q4 EPS that matched expectations, along with Q4 revenue that beat views. The genealogy website expects Q1 sales of $86 million to $88 million, well above the Street's consensus forecast of $81.3 million. Ancestry.com, which went public in 2009, has staged its first pullback to its 10-week moving average since clearing a base with a buy point at 30.80. It has an IBD Composite Rating of 95. The stock initially slipped after the close, but then recovered.

Salesforce.com (CRM) gained after the closing bell, too. The maker of customer relationship management software said after the close that Q4 EPS and revenue topped estimates. Salesforce sees Q1 EPS below forecasts, but it guided Q1 revenue above views. The stock has been consolidating and trading near its 10-week moving average. It has a 91 Composite Rating.

For Friday, the highly rated companies slated to post earnings include IPG Photonics (IPGP) and Warner Chilcott (WCRX). Friday's economic reports will include an updated Q4 GDP figure and new consumer sentiment data.

Stocks ended mixed Friday, but notched their third straight weekly gain. Techs outshined on the session, thanks to upbeat earnings from Oracle (ORCL) and Research In Motion (RIMM). Both big-caps reported late Thursday.

Stocks ended mixed Friday, but notched their third straight weekly gain. Techs outshined on the session, thanks to upbeat earnings from Oracle (ORCL) and Research In Motion (RIMM). Both big-caps reported late Thursday.

The Nasdaq stretched its win streak to eight sessions, rising 0.5%. That's the longest hot streak since a 12-session marathon in July 2009.

Meanwhile, the S&P 500 rose 0.1%. But it pared gains after hitting resistance at the 1131 level. Meanwhile, the Dow also gained 0.1%, while the NYSE composite fell 0.2%. Turnover surged across the board due to the expiration of options and futures.
For the week, the Nasdaq rose 3.3% and NYSE composite 1.2%. The Dow and S&P 500 gained 1.4% each.

Thinly traded 51job (JOBS) rocketed 13% to a five-year high. The stock followed up after clearing a short consolidation Thursday. China-based 51job is a provider of human resources services. It has delivered three straight quarters of triple-digit earnings growth.

IPG Photonic (IPGP) rallied 4% and touched a fresh three-year high in fast trade. The stock cleared a 19.30 buy point on Aug. 3 on a cup base, and has gained 23%. IPG makes lasers for materials processing, telecom and medical applications. Analysts see its full-year earnings skyrocketing 542%. The stock is No. 53 in this week's IBD 100.

Radware (RDWR) gained 5% in nearly triple its average volume. The Israeli networking firm has gained 34% this week on reports that it may be a takeover target. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and IBM (IBM) have been named as potential suitors. Radware has shot up more than 50% from a 24.10 buy point in a cup-with-handle base cleared Aug. 24.

Energy XXI (EXXI) reversed early losses and rose 3% in nearly double its average volume. The stock cleared a 21.45 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Earlier this month, the oil and gas producer reported fiscal Q4 earnings of 20 cents a share, smashing views of a nickel. Analysts see its full-year earnings surging 170%.

On the downside, Sina (SINA) reversed from a two-year high and dropped 5% in more than three times normal volume. Despite the downturn, the stock still sits 4% past a 46.02 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.
The National Association of Home Builder's housing market index will be out Monday along with earnings from homebuilder Lennar (LEN).
