The IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks this week is built in part on a diverse group of computer hardware makers. 3D Systems (DDD) and 3D printing system rival Stratasys (SSYS) have been standouts for several months and were big IBD 50 stock winners last week. But here are six other tech hardware firms that are making their mark. The…

Past performance is no guarantee of a future winner. But a track record of success is a pretty good sign. IBD Screen Of The Day Top Fundamentals narrows down stocks to those with a three-year EPS and sales growth of at least 25%. Those at the top of the list do better. Far better. No. 1 on the screen is…
The IBD 50 lists top-rated stocks and is a good place to search for watch-list candidates.
It's earnings season and companies are showing their true colors in quarterly reports. Here are the top 5 companies in the elite IBD 50 on tap to report earnings the coming week.
Fashion house and retailer Michael Kors (KORS) is No. 8 on the IBD 50, and will announce fiscal third quarter earnings Tuesday before the market opens.
Analysts expect Kors to report an 86% surge in earnings per share, to 41 cents. Revenue is forecast to climb 45% to $540.3 million.
Shares of premium lifestyle apparel, accessories and fragrance maker Ralph Lauren (RL), which is not an IBD 50 stock, jumped 5.9% Wednesday after it solidly beat targets on strong holiday sales.
Kors went public in December 2011 at 20 and grew rapidly. Shares are trading above 50-day and 200-day averages, about 4% off the 52-week high.

It hit an all-time high of 60 on Jan. 28, but closed down that day and slid for several sessions before finding support at its 50-day line last week and rebounding. Shares rose 0.8% in Friday's stock market.
Kors sells watches made by Fossil (FOSL), which is not on the latest IBD 50. But Fossil reports earnings Tuesday as well.

Generator maker Generac (GNRC) is No. 17 on the IBD 50. Its products were in hot demand last week amid preparations for a major storm along the Eastern seaboard, dubbed Nemo. Generac gapped up 20% on Oct. 31 during Superstorm Sandy, then consolidated until it got another boost from Nemo.
When Generac reports Q4 results early Thursday, consensus is for EPS to fall 9% to 69 cents, and for sales to grow 16% to $309.4 million. Its stock ended the week at an all-time high 40.54.

TripAdvisor (TRIP) is No. 31 on the list. It's a spin-off from online travel company Expedia.com (EXPE). The stock fell 2% Wednesday after reporting earnings that badly missed estimates despite Expedia's record hotel bookings.
TripAdvisor lets travelers share trip reviews. like Kors, it's a December 2011 IPO that's done well since.

Shares turned up on Nov. 2 after its Q3 earnings report and have climbed 64%, to a 47.02 close Friday. The stock spiked Wednesday early on Expedia's results, but closed little changed that day. Wall Street is looking for Q4 EPS of 26 cents, up 3 cents from last year. Sales are forecast to rise 21% to $167.1 million.

Discovery (DISCA) is No. 36 on the IBD 50 and the world's No. 1 nonfiction media company with networks such as Discovery Channel, TLC and Animal Planet. It announces Q4 results early Thursday. Also reporting Feb. 14: CBS (CBS), which is trading at a 52-week high, and DirecTV (DTV), just 3% off its high.

Analysts expect DirecTV to report an 11% earnings per share decline to 76 cents, and for revenue to grow a modest 7% to $1.2 billion. From its October 2008 bottom in the Great Recession, shares have shot up 613%, closing at 71.47 Friday.

Jarden (JAH) is a diversified manufacturer that makes Sunbeam kitchen mixers, Coleman camping tents, First Alert smoke detectors, Bicycle playing cards and and many other well-known consumer and outdoor products.

The No. 36 company on the list is forecast to report a 31% gain in EPS to $1.26, and a 4% advance in revenue to $1.81 billion. Since Dec. 31, Jarden's stock has risen in all but five days. Friday it closed at a fresh all-time high of 60.82.
Bonus: IPG Photonics (IPGP) reports on Friday. The maker of optical fiber-based lasers for materials processing and other applications is No. 50 on the IBD 50.

Some disappointing economic data made for a shaky start to Wednesday's session, but stocks managed to pare at least some losses by day's end.
Some disappointing economic data made for a shaky start to Wednesday's session, but stocks managed to pare at least some losses by day's end.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the latest Market Wrap video!

When the closing bell rang, the NYSE composite sank 0.9%, the S&P 500 fell 0.7% and the Nasdaq composite dropped 0.5%. Volume increased on the NYSE and Nasdaq, according to unconfirmed data. At the day's low, the S&P 500 stood 1.1% below Tuesday's close. The Nasdaq came back from a 1.2% loss.
Economic data didn't help the market. The April ADP Employer Services report showed a 179,000 add to U.S. jobs, less than what most economists expected.
And the Institute for Supply Management's index of nonmanufacturing companies fell to 52.8 in April from 57.3 in March, a good deal worse than expected. Readings greater than 50 reflect growth.
A reading that gauges new orders dropped by the most since record keeping began in 1997.
A number of leaders put in steep losses.

Restaurant reservation website OpenTable (OPEN) gapped down and plunged 16% in five times its usual trade. A better-than-expected Q1 report was overshadowed by some top-level executive changes at the firm.

Stratasys (SSYS), a maker of three-dimensional prototyping systems, dived 14% in 2 1/2 times its usual volume. Oil producer Brigham Exploration (BEXP) fell 10%, while telecom equipment maker Harris (HRS) lost 8%.

Specialty chemicals maker Polypore (PPO) fell 5% in fast trade in the regular session. But the stock closed in the upper half of its trading range. And its quarterly report, released after the close, pushed the stock higher.
IPG Photonics (IPGP), a maker of fiber-optic lasers used in the telecom, medical and defense industries, fell 4% in heavy volume. But, like Polypore, IPG closed in the upper half of the day's range.
On the other side of the coin, Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR) climbed 6% in 3 1/2 times its average trade, but closed much nearer the day's low than the day's high.

But another blowout report from Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) sent that stock screaming 19% higher in triple-paced trade. While it also ended in the lower half of the day's trading range, that calculation does not take into account a huge trading gap.

Look for more earnings reports Thursday from Priceline (PCLN), Visa (V) and Spreadtrum Communications (SPRD). The key economic reports due Thursday include the latest figure on jobless claims, productivity and sales data from retailers.

Critics have panned Apple's  (AAPL) attempt at its own mapping service, favoring Google's  (GOOG) tried and true Google Maps app. Investors like Google as well, as the Internet giant rejoins the IBD 50 list of top-ranked companies on Monday at No. 40 — Apple's already high on the IBD 50 list. SS&C Technologies (SSNC), Randgold Resources (GOLD), Genpact[ticker…
Lately, the Electronics-Scientific Measuring industry group has been as reliable as a fine Swiss watch.
Week in, week out it has been among the top 20 in IBD's 197 industry groups, based on six-month price performance.
It's No. 20 this week, up from 75 seven months ago.
Most of the group's surge relative to the S&P 500 has come since the market trough in late August.
The group has benefited from several macro trends. Those range from the explosion in bandwidth capacity to the graying of America and the rest of the world.
"The group's products and services are diverse," said Dana Cease, analyst for John Hancock Asset Management. "Its companies benefit from a wide range of macro forces."
The group has two subsets: life sciences and diagnostics in one camp, and electronics in the other.
Life sciences tends to have steadier revenue and earnings than the electronics subset.
"Their customers are more price-elastic," Cease said. "They are hospitals, R&D centers and universities, which often pay whatever its new equipment costs."
M&A activity in late 2010 spotlighted two deals that featured high premiums. Danaher's (DHR) takeover bid pushed Beckman Coulter (BEC) to 72 from 57. Now it's settled in at 83.
Thermo Fisher Scientific's (TMO) acquisition pushed Dionex (DNEX) to 118 from 98.
Life sciences-diagnostics companies also sell a lot of consumables, such as test tubes and microscope slides. Those use-and-replace add-ons have much higher margins than their host machines.
For every host machine companies sell, they tend to sell an equal dollar amount of consumables within five years, Cease says.
Mettler-Toledo (MTD) is up 55% from a year ago. After breaking out of a basing pattern to a new high Feb. 8, the stock ran up 11% and then pulled back to its 10-week line, where it's found support.
Earnings growth climbed back above 20% the past three quarters after stumbling the prior six.
This maker of scales is adept at organic growth through acquisition, Cease says.
Analysts expect Bruker's (BRKR) Q1 earnings to jump 50% on a 23% increase in sales. A member of the IBD 50, its stock is extended after recently jumping off its 10-week moving average line.
Firms in the electronics subset make test and measurement gear. The products are used to vet new gizmos used in telecom networks, data centers and chip applications, as well as routing and switching.
The Electronics Side
The electronics subset is more volatile. It had a bigger jump off the market bottom.
IPG Photonics (IPGP), a leading maker of fiber-optic lasers, has four quarters of triple-digit EPS growth. Those followed four stanzas of declines.
Bob Auer, manager of $232 million Auer Growth Fund , likes Newport (NEWP). Like IPG, it is a maker of lasers and related gear. Its products are used in everything from eye surgery to missile defense.
Auer is bullish on Newport through 2011. He likes the company's fast growth, increase in backlogs and guidance for sales to hit an all-time record.

Cease is slightly more bullish on the electronics segment. But recent top individual price gainers in either subset will likely yield to new names, he says.Lately, the Electronics-Scientific Measuring industry group has been as reliable as a fine Swiss watch.Week in, week out it has been among the top 20 in IBD's 197 industry groups, based on six-month price performance.It's No. 20 this week, up from 75 seven months ago.Most of the group's surge relative to the S&P 500 has come since the market trough in late August.The group has benefited from several macro trends. Those use-and-replace add-ons have much higher margins than their host machines.For every host machine companies sell, they tend to sell an equal dollar amount of consumables within five years, Cease says.Mettler-Toledo (MTD) is up 55% from a year ago. After breaking out of a basing pattern to a new high Feb. 8, the stock ran up 11% and then pulled back to its 10-week line, where it's found support.Earnings growth climbed back above 20% the past three quarters after stumbling the prior six.This maker of scales is adept at organic growth through acquisition, Cease says.Analysts expect Bruker's (BRKR) Q1 earnings to jump 50% on a 23% increase in sales. A member of the IBD 50, its stock is extended after recently jumping off its 10-week moving average line.Firms in the electronics subset make test and measurement gear. The products are used to vet new gizmos used in telecom networks, data centers and chip applications, as well as routing and switching.The Electronics SideThe electronics subset is more volatile. It had a bigger jump off the market bottom.IPG Photonics (IPGP), a leading maker of fiber-optic lasers, has four quarters of triple-digit EPS growth. Those followed four stanzas of declines.Bob Auer, manager of $232 million Auer Growth Fund , likes Newport (NEWP). Like IPG, it is a maker of lasers and related gear. Its products are used in everything from eye surgery to missile defense.Auer is bullish on Newport through 2011. He likes the company's fast growth, increase in backlogs and guidance for sales to hit an all-time record.Cease is slightly more bullish on the electronics segment. But recent top individual price gainers in either subset will likely yield to new names, he says.

U.S. stock and options markets were set to remain closed for a second day Tuesday, as Hurricane Sandy's storm surge flooded parts of New York City and pounded much of the east coast with heavy rains. Electronic platforms for equity index and futures trading were open overnight, closing at 8:15 a.m. EDT.
CME Group closed the NYMEX trading floor, but maintained normal electronic trading of commodities and other futures and options.

In stocks,BP  (BP) reported a 5% gain in third quarter earnings. Topping analyst expectations for a 19% decline.  Revenue slipped 5% to $93.1 billion, better than the 9% drop expected by analysts. The company also boosted its dividend more than 12%, to nine cents a share. BP agreed last week to sell half of its Russian joint venture TNK-BP to Russian state-owned oil operator Rosneft for 17.1 billion in cash and a 13% stake in Rosneft.

Grain trader and agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland  (ADM)  reported adjusted EPS of 45 cents, topping consensus estimates of 35 cents. Revenue slipped 4%, less than forecast. Profit at the company's oilseed processing unit, its second-largest business by revenue, doubled to $336 million.

Allergan (AGN), Impax Laboratories  (IPXL) and IPG Photnics  (IPGP) are scheduled to release earnings Tuesday. Polypore International  (PPO), PriceSmart  (PSMT) and Triumph Group (TGI) were among those set to report after what would normally be the market's close.

Overseas, stocks across Europe muscled up to solid gains at midday. The CAC-40 in Paris led, up 1.1%. China’s major indexes were narrowly mixed. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slumped 1% after the Bank of Japan increased the size of its asset buying stimulus program.The dollar slipped vs. the euro, as Italy’s borrowing costs slipped to the lowest levels in more than a year.

Commodities were little changed, with oil hovering just above $86 a barrel and gold at $1,714 an ounce. In recent years, industrial manufacturers have gravitated from carbon dioxide lasers to fiber lasers. That's good news for IPG Photonics (IPGP).

The Oxford, Mass.-based company makes fiber lasers for industrial use. From heavy industrial machinery to medical surgical equipment, these lasers are gaining popularity thanks to their energy efficiency, better beam quality and faster cutting speeds.

Manufacturers also find that fiber lasers require less maintenance while providing greater value than carbon dioxide lasers. IPG Photonics' proprietary optical fiber technology enables it to make powerful fiber lasers and amplifiers for materials processing and data transmission.
"IPG Photonics sells about 65% to 66% of fiber lasers in the world," said Mark Miller, senior equity analyst with Noble Financial Capital Markets in Danville, Calif. "They dominate that space."
A Brainy Founder

Unlike some of its rivals, IPG Photonics makes its own lasers as well as sells them. Because the company is vertically integrated, it can control the quality of its products more closely and lower its production costs.

"More than 50% of the cost of a fiber laser is in the diode bars," Miller said. "IPG Photonics makes these diode bars internally. That helps them bring down costs significantly, giving them a price advantage over their competitors."
He adds that JDS Uniphase (JDSU), which makes communications test and measurement tools, is one of the few other companies that develop their own diode bars. It's one of IPG Photonics' main rivals.

Valentin Gapontsev, 72, a Russian-born specialist in laser physics and technology, has been the company's chairman and chief executive since he founded it in 1990. Gapontsev, who previously served as department chair at the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, won the 2010 Russian Federation National Award in Science and Technology for his fiber laser innovations.
Fast Growth

Miller has followed IPG Photonics for about four years. In the year after the company's initial public offering in December 2006, Miller became a fan because of the company's vertical integration. He says that fiber lasers cut metals at higher speeds and are adaptable to wide-ranging industrial environments, making them a better option than carbon dioxide lasers for everything from welding pipes to building auto bodies.
Global manufacturers' growing acceptance of fiber lasers has enabled IPG Photonics to increase market share. Its revenues increased 61% in 2010 to $299 million.

"Typically, laser firms will grow a couple of percentage points above GDP," added Miller, a trained physicist who worked as a Silicon Valley research scientist before becoming an analyst. "But IPG Photonics has around a 25% compound annual growth rate since 2006."In recent years, industrial manufacturers have gravitated from carbon dioxide lasers to fiber lasers. International stocks, in the broadest sense, are sometimes based in the U.S.But some U.S.-based companies get most of their revenue outside the country.Let's look at three IBD 50 stocks and one blue chip that fit that description.IPG Photonics (IPGP) makes fiber lasers for industrial uses. The company is based in Massachusetts, but last year about 82% of revenue came from outside North America.Annual earnings grew 842% in 2010 and 113% in 2011. Revenue jumped 61% and 59%, respectively, in those periods.IPG made several acquisitions in 2010-11, but they weren't the growth drivers. The drivers were new products and a growing market acceptance of fiber lasers, along with a rebound from a depressed world economy in 2009.The Street expects 19% EPS growth this year on a 19% revenue pop. Q4 results are expected to be reported in early February.IPG is slightly extended from a 61.61 buy point in a double-bottom base.Western Digital (WDC), a California-based hard drive maker, derives about 77% of revenue from outside the Americas. In Q3, Asia accounted for 59% of revenue.Annual earnings fell 46% in fiscal 2011 ended in June and leapt 162% in fiscal 2012. Revenue fell 3% and rose 31% those same periods.The Street sees an 11% drop in EPS this fiscal year on an 18% revenue gain.The stock is climbing the right side of a cup base.Online marketer eBay (EBAY) receives about 52% of its revenue from outside the U.S. Ten years ago, the international footprint was 7%.Annual earnings grew 9% in 2010 and 17% in 2011. Revenue improved 5% and 27%. The Street expects 16% EPS growth this year on a 21% revenue spurt.The stock is modestly above a flat base and could be forming a base-on-base pattern.Blue chip heavy equipment maker Caterpillar (CAT) is the only stock in this group that isn't in the IBD 50.The company is based in Peoria, Ill., but 63% of Q3 revenue came from outside North America.Annual EPS rose 120% and 77% in 2010-11 on revenue gains of 31% and 41%. The Street expects a 20% EPS pop on a 9% sales gain.The stock has a respectable 82 Composite Rating but is 25% off its high.

When the road gets rough, most folks tighten their grip on the wheel.But how exactly do you do that with stocks?The most common strategy for growth investors in a correcting market is to move to cash. But there are sometimes signals that a correction may be short-lived. Or, investors may own a stock that appears set to advance despite the overall market conditions.These are just two of many reasons that may urge growth investors to decide not to take profits and rotate entirely to cash. Under these and other circumstances, two of your most effective offensive precautions include scaling down your price target and narrowing your loss allowance to less than 5%.In the healthy market, your nominal price target on stocks might be 20%. IBD founder William O'Neil, in his book "The Successful Investor," recommends "selling a few of your stocks when they are up 20% to 25% from your purchase price."Investors using the price-to-earnings expansion method may chart sell points well beyond 20%.But correcting markets are stingy and unpredictable. Gains of 10% or more can be tough to muster. And a 10% gain can turn into a quick loss in the first few seconds of a panicked trading session.It happens to even the most fundamentally sound stocks.To defend against such volatility, narrow your top-end target to 10% to 15%. Consider taking profit even earlier — at 3% to 5%, for example. Remember, pulling off a pair of 5% to 10% wins in a correcting market leaves you well above where you would have been if you'd rotated entirely to cash. And it puts you far above those who watched their holdings correct along with the market.Impax Laboratories (IPXL) broke out of a first-stage, base-on-base pattern 1 just as the market was starting to correct in September. It rose 9% through Oct. 2, then pulled back and dropped below support at the 10-week moving average. It collapsed Oct. 31 in massive trade. A downsized sell target could have captured the bulk of that advance.Cirrus Logic (CRUS), Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) and IPG Photonics (IPGP) are among other leaders also to come under stress in the current correction.On the downside, don't wait for the normal 7% to 8% loss to exit a stock. Dips, especially in heavy volume and those that break support at their 50-day or 10-week moving averages, tend to rapidly worsen in correcting markets.Tighten your baseline loss allowance. If you use trading stops, set them to a 3% to 5% maximum. For investors with a high risk tolerance, this can be a tough sacrifice. It means being shaken out of some stocks that dip 5% or 7%, then turn and run higher.

EZchip Semiconductor (EZCH) fell after it reported quarterly results and warned of weak Q1 sales.  EZchip slumped as much as 16% intraday and sliced its 50-day line but cut its loss to less than 5%. Volume was already six times its daily average of 329,000 shares. The stock was ranked No. 7 in Monday's IBD 50.

On the upside, Whole Foods Market (WFMI) soared 12% in huge volume. It was the stock's second upward gap since November. The stock is now up 51% from a 40.43 buy point in a long cup with handle. The six-day handle began to form Oct. 25.

Late Wednesday, the high-end grocer posted a 59% increase in December fiscal first-quarter profit to 51 cents a share. That marked an EPS increase of more than 25% in five of the past six quarters. Sales grew 14% to $3 billion, marking the fourth straight quarter of double-digit increases. That's an improvement from a string of low single-digit increases seen from Q3 of 2008 to Q3 of 2009.

IPG Photonics (IPGP) gapped up at the open and vaulted 30% to new highs. The stock has rallied 136% since breaking out of a cup pattern at 19.30 in early August. The Oxford, Mass.-based maker of pulsed and high-power lasers boosted its Q4 sales guidance to $100 million, up 84% from year-ago levels, from a $80 million to $86 million range. It also expects to earn 53 to 56 cents a share, compared with previous guidance of 30-35 cents. It earned 7 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. CEO Valentin Gapontsev noted "broad-based demand strength" and that China and Europe were "stand-out performers for the quarter." The Oxford, Mass.-based maker of pulsed and high-power lasers boosted its Q4 sales guidance to $100 million, up 84% from year-ago levels, from a $80 million to $86 million range. It also expects to earn 53 to 56 cents a share, compared with previous guidance of 30-35 cents. It earned 7 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. CEO Valentin Gapontsev noted "broad-based demand strength" and that China and Europe were "stand-out performers for the quarter." IPG plans to report results on Feb. 25.

While known as a staple in chipmaking, lasers also are used to manufacture everything from razor blades to jet engines, and companies such as IPG Photonics  (IPGP) and Newport (NEWP) see the list of applications growing.
Smaller sizes and lower costs have made lasers easier to incorporate in precision tools, replacing older technologies in factories and research labs.
"You can do things with a laser that you just can't do with a mechanical blade," said Newport CEO Bob Phillippy.
Lasers aren't just for cutting and welding. They're also used in scientific instruments, like those that generate images of cell membranes and what lies underneath them.
Military To Civilian
The military has long used lasers in targeting and surveillance, areas that could expand into some civilian uses, Phillippy says.

Laser makers IPG Photonics, Newport, Coherent (COHR) and Rofin-Sinar (RSTI) have been logging double- and triple-digit profit and sales growth in recent quarters, helped by a rebounding manufacturing sector and federal stimulus spending.

Fiber-based lasers and their lower operating costs also have been replacing gas-based lasers as users upgrade, says Mark Miller, an analyst with Noble Financial. Shares of IPG, which is especially known for its fiber-based lasers, have doubled this year. Coherent, Rofin-Sinar and Newport also make fiber-based lasers.
Other factors helping laser makers include a revival among their chipmaker customers and the shifting of production to China, which boosts profit margins, Miller says.
The end of stimulus spending and the cyclical nature of chipmaking are challenges, but laser makers are aided by having a diverse set of products and customers, he says.
"It limits their exposure," Miller said.
Some trends favor laser makers.
For example, carmakers are adopting use of lasers to produce lighter, more fuel-efficient cars.

Bill Shiner, IPG's vice president of industrial sales, says the car industry was slow to embrace fiber-based lasers, but IPG's laser sales to carmakers have taken off the past few years as the auto field began to recover and consumers started demanding better gas mileage.

IPG's fiber-based lasers are good at penetrating the high-strength steel that car companies prefer for their lighter weight, Shiner says. Also, making car batteries, including those for hybrid and electric vehicles, is easier using laser welding.
Laser prices have fallen, so more plants can afford to retool and upgrade for high-volume, high-precision manufacturing.
Newer lasers are more powerful, use less energy and need less maintenance than older versions, Shiner says. Even diamond-based cutters, an alternative to lasers, wear out.
"Finally, it's cost-justifiable," he said. "It's just made things much more doable."
In new, fuel-efficient jet engines, lasers are used to drill millions of tiny holes in surfaces to keep the components cool, Shiner says.
The wind-energy sector is looking to lasers to improve the corrosion resistance of turbines, which can be covered with another metal in a process called laser cladding, he says.
Conventional energy companies like oil and gas drillers are also turning to laser cladding to refurbish their drill bits and pipes.
Solar Picture Also Bright
Solar energy has been shining on lasers as well, though Noble's Miller says the alternative energy industry is still a relatively small share of manufacturers' business.

Lasers are needed in manufacturing thin-film solar cells because mechanical systems can't quickly and accurately etch tiny lines and holes in the film, said Phillippy. A mechanical tool can't make a hole a millionth of a meter wide.
Even if the solar module market doesn't pan out, due to cuts in government subsidies or other factors, laser makers like Newport will be OK, Phillippy said.

He sees more uses in scientific research, including gene sequencing and diagnostics. Utilization of lasers to correct vision impairment and to carve custom dental and medical implants also will grow, he says.
Military technology like night-vision optics could find its way in commercial applications like car safety features and security cameras, he says.
Advances in technology that have made lasers easier to use, smaller, more efficient and less costly will continue, Phillippy says, expanding the range of potential applications.

"You don't have to make just one bet," he said.While known as a staple in chipmaking, lasers also are used to manufacture everything from razor blades to jet engines, and companies such as IPG Photonics  (IPGP) and Newport (NEWP) see the list of applications growing.Smaller sizes and lower costs have made lasers easier to incorporate in precision tools, replacing older technologies in factories and research labs."You can do things with a laser that you just can't do with a mechanical blade," said Newport CEO Bob Phillippy.Lasers aren't just for cutting and welding. IBD's 20 Rules: An Investor's Corner Series
Thirteenth In A Series
"Owner-operated" is always a good sign, whether stenciled on a big-rig truck or a leading stock.

In either case, it means those at the controls have a higher-than-usual interest in piloting the vehicle safely and profitably. In stocks, there are a number of ways to track down the percentage of outstanding shares owned by management.

The company descriptions in the Weekly IBD 50 lists include percentage of management ownership. In the most recent list, management of both Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Arcos Dorados (ARCO) owned more than 30% of shares outstanding. IPG Photonics (IPGP) took the prize, however, with 42% of shares owned by company executives.

The Big Cap 20 list also shows management ownership. By nature, big-cap stocks are generally older and have been public longer with much larger numbers of shares. Management naturally owns smaller portions. The biggest share of management ownership on the most recent Big Cap 20 list was Amazon.com (AMZN), with a 20% share in management's keeping.

You can also find management ownership data using the E-Tables tool at investors.com. Just click on the "View Expanded Stock Data" function in the red band just below the Index tabs. This tool also allows you to sort by management ownership to quickly find stocks with strong management holdings.

Management held a 31% piece of stun gun maker Taser (TASR) when it started its epic run in April 2003. The stock ran up more than 4,000% in 12 months. By the peak, management ownership had dropped to 15%. The stock has never come close to that high again. Today, management holds 8% of the company's shares.

This is not to say that companies with lesser management ownership don't do well. Stocks often excel with minuscule management-share figures. And you would not want to use the percentage of management ownership as a sole or even a leading metric in choosing a stock. But it can act as a reinforcing piece of data.
So as you line up your pluses and minuses in fundamental research, don't ignore this factor, which suggests management is thoroughly vested in seeing that share prices do well.

Another good example is Garmin Industries (GRMN). The innovative developer of global positioning equipment came public in December of 2000. When it cleared its initial base two years later, management owned 47% of the company's shares.
The stock climbed more than 900% over the next five years. When it peaked in October 2007, management still owned 47%. Today management's share is still healthy, but a much more modest 23%.

The Nasdaq took a breather Monday after eight straight gains, slipping 0.1%. The NYSE fell the same amount. The Dow and the S&P 500 each added less than 0.1%.

Volume ran higher on the NYSE through most of the session, but dried up late in the day to finish lower on both exchanges.

Jinko Solar Holdings (JKS) was the day's big winner, up 17% in huge trade after its Q3 earnings blowout. Earnings per share vaulted to $1.75 a share vs. $0.09 a year ago as revenue jumped 267% to $215 million.
IPG Photonics (IPGP) blasted ahead 8% in heavy trade. It easily cleared analysts' Q3 expectations and raised its Q4 guidance above current consensus views.
Herbalife (HLF) rose 2% in regular trade, ahead of its after-hours earnings release. Analyst consensus calls for a 21% gain in earnings on 14% growth in sales.

The calendar shows no real data on tap until Wednesday, when mortgage applications, Challenger job cuts and ADP employment data hit the wires. Election returns will also be rolling in late Tuesday, and on Wednesday, the Federal Open Market Committee will issue a decision on further potential stimulus measures.

Leading stocks fared well Tuesday as the market staged a soft rebound from Monday's sell-off.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 warmed up 0.1%. The NYSE moved 0.2% higher. Volume was tracking lower on both major exchanges compared with the same time Monday.

The gains were broad, with 90% of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD advancing. Defensive industries, such as drugstore chains and diversified operations, moved generally lower. Truck makers, computer gaming providers, shoemakers and steel producers posted the strongest advances.

Among leading stocks, Robbins & Myers (RBN) swept up 4% in heavy trade. That put the maker of components for oil exploration and processing even with its 10-week moving average. The stock, which holds a 97 Composite Rating from IBD, is in its fourth week of consolidation and has been below its 10-week line since April 6.
Lululemon Athletica (LULU)climbed 3%, advancing to new highs in strong trade. The Canada-based retailer of fashion workout apparel is extended after clearing a six-week flat base March 28.

IPG Photonics (IPGP) rocketed out of a square-box base, gapping up to a 6% gain in powerful trade. The laser instrument maker moved to new highs and was just above the 61.73 buy point. The stock holds a Composite Rating of 98.

Mesabi's profit skyrocketed 138% to 4,100% in the past three quarters, while sales surged between 122% and 2,574% over the same period.OpenTable (OPEN) rose 3% and came close to a 76.79 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. The auto replacement parts maker's stock had reversed from an all-time high last week.

Stocks finished mixed with higher volume Tuesday in the last full session before two big economic announcements. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each added 0.5%. But the Nasdaq, weighed by ugly moves among some tech issues, gave up a fraction. The Philadelphia semiconductor index fell 0.7%. Volume increased on both major exchanges, according to preliminary data.…
Stocks turned mixed early Tuesday afternoon as improved retail sales and inflation data tempered concerns about a brewing fight over raising the nation's debt ceiling.

The Nasdaq was down 0.3% while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were down a fraction after paring earlier losses. Volume was down 2% on the Nasdaq and up 2% on the NYSE compared with the same time Monday.

Apple (AAPL) fell for a second day, hitting an 11-month low, following reports that the company had cut orders for iPhone 5 components amid weakening demand. The stock was down 2% in almost double its average daily volume, breaking through support at 500.
Nomura Securities on Tuesday lowered its price target on Apple to 530 from 660 on "signs of weaker-than-expected iPhone 5 sales."
Meanwhile, generic drugmaker Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) climbed 2% in strong trade as it attempts to get back to its 50-day line.

The stock boasts a 98 Earnings Per Share Rating, just shy of a best-possible 99. However, profit growth has slowed for three straight quarters, rising 24% in the latest period. Revenue growth has also slowed sharply.
SodaStream International (SODA), which makes in-home soda beverage machines, was up 1%. It's extended 14% beyond a 43.10 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.
The stock has an Accumulation-Distribution Rating of A, indicating strong demand.
On the downside, IPG Photonics (IPGP), a maker of fiber-optic lasers, lost 2% in heavy volume as it came off a 52-week high. It's extended 10% past a 61.61 buy point from a double-bottom base.
Also, Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU), a rival to Chinese online search giant Baidu (BIDU), was down 2% in healthy turnover. It's still 27% past a 24.40 buy point;

Retail sales and producer price data released Tuesday indicated that the economy continues to slowly improve amid tame inflation. Retail sales rose 0.5% in December, or 0.3% minus auto sales. The breakout from a sound base isn't the only time an investor can establish a position in a great stock.
A brief pullback to within 5% of the correct buy point offers a second chance. Sometimes a stock will shake out remaining sellers before resuming its climb.

The first or second time a stock retests its 50-day moving average (or 10-week moving average line on a weekly chart) in tame volume presents another chance to add shares to an existing stake. Such orderly declines are essential to a sustained price move.Wait for the stock to rebound higher in heavy turnover before you buy.

Priceline.com (PCLN) notched a new high of 358.24 last week before finishing the week 2% lower at 337.82. This week, the online travel agent has lost more ground, but weekly volume has been tame, just like the prior week.

It's trading closer to the 10-week moving average, where the stock has found support in past rallies. Large funds often buy shares when a strong stock has declined to its 10-week line in order to continue building their position while keeping their average cost as low as possible. Priceline finished Thursday 10% above a 302.08 short-stroke follow-on buy point.

Last week, fellow travel agent Ctrip.com (CTRP) rallied sharply Sept. 27 and stood as much as 13% above its 43.48 buy point in a choppy base-within-a-base pattern. Since then, the stock has fallen in five of the past eight sessions. On Thursday, Ctrip.com made an intraday low of 44.86, just 3% above the buy point.

IPG Photonics (IPGP) ended Thursday off 0.54 at 22.39. Stocks pushed to new session highs in late trading, boosted by a weakening dollar.The Nasdaq climbed 0.9% to just below its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 also neared its 50-day line, rising 0.5%. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite rose 0.6%. Volume was tracking lower across the board.IPG Photonics (IPGP) rallied 6% to a record high in fast trade. The stock cleared a short consolidation. IPG makes lasers used in materials processing, communications and medical applications. It has delivered triple-digit profit in the past three quarters and analysts see another in the current period.Semtech (SMTC) pulled back after hitting a nearly nine-year high earlier. Shares were still up 3% in heavy trading. The chip designer gapped up at the open and was up as much as 8% after delivering Q1 results above expectations late Wednesday.On the downside, Lululemon Athletica (LULU) extended its loss to 4% and came close to its 50-day moving average. With about two hours left in the trading session, the stock has already traded its average daily volume of about 2 million shares. Earlier, FBR Capital Markets downgraded the yoga apparel retailer to underperform from market perform on margin concerns.
Leading stocks were active in pre-market trading Friday, and stock futures signaled a higher open despite a softer-than-expected report on fourth-quarter GDP growth.
Dow futures rose 62 points before the bell. S&P 500 futures were 8.1 points higher, while Nasdaq 100 futures added 18.25 points. All were above fair market value.

The Department of Commerce cut its view of Q4 GDP growth to 2.8%, down from its initial 3.2% estimate. Economists had expected an increase to 3.3%. The release cited cutbacks in government spending and lagging private sector investment. The estimate of consumer spending was cut from 4.4% to 4.1%.

Among leading stocks, Deckers Outdoor (DECK) climbed 5% before the bell. Late Thursday, the shoe company said Q4 earnings rose 31% to $2.27 a share, well above forecasts. Sales cleared views as well, rising 24% to $430.1 million. Deckers boosted its Q1 revenue guidance above consensus and also lifted its full-year revenue and earnings guidance above expectations.

The pre-market jump hoisted Deckers shares 7% above an 87.98 buy point in an eight-week cup base. The stock had slipped 6% below that mark after its initial breakout attempt, testing 10-week support without triggering the 7% to 8% sell rule.

Riverbed Technology  (RVBD) climbed 3% in the pre-open. The maker of network performance and cloud computing solutions rebounded 7% Thursday after a gentle pullback to its 10-week moving average. It was the fifth pullback since its most recent breakout in July.

Meanwhile, laser and fiber optic equipment maker IPG Photonics (IPGP) beamed up 3% in pre-market action. The Oxford, Mass.-based company reported Q4 earnings of 56 cents a share, 3 cents above views. Revenue rose 86% to $101 million, above expectations for $98.8 million. The company also boosted its first-quarter sales and earnings guidance.

IPG is set up in a possible short stroke pattern with a 55.56 buy point. But it is extended 110% above its 40 week moving average. Anything more than 70% above that line is generally considered due for a correction.Leading stocks were active in pre-market trading Friday, and stock futures signaled a higher open despite a softer-than-expected report on fourth-quarter GDP growth.Dow futures rose 62 points before the bell. S&P 500 futures were 8.1 points higher, while Nasdaq 100 futures added 18.25 points. All were above fair market value.The Department of Commerce cut its view of Q4 GDP growth to 2.8%, down from its initial 3.2% estimate. Economists had expected an increase to 3.3%. Stocks slipped from session highs, but were still modestly higher in late trading Monday.The NYSE composite rose 0.3%, thanks to energy, steel, mining and oil-related groups. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 edged up 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Volume turned lower on both exchanges after being higher on the Nasdaq during the morning.IPG Photonics (IPGP) jumped 11% to a record high in heavy trading. The stock recently found support at its 10-week moving average. On Thursday, the maker of laser tools guided Q4 2010 earnings and sales well ahead of views. It officially reports results Feb. 25.Walter Energy (WLT) bolted 6% and regained its 50-day moving average, ahead of its Q4 numbers after the close. Analysts see the coal producer's profit surging 350% to $1.98 a share. Revenue is expected at $434.9 million, up 84%. The stock is working on a new base after correcting just over 15% from its January peak.But Agilent Technologies (A) turned tail with a small decline in subpar volume after reaching a 10-year high of 45.65. The scientific equipment maker will report fiscal Q1 results after the close. Analysts see earnings rising 53% to 58 cents a share. Sales are slated to rise 28% to about $1.55 billion.Clorox (CLX) dropped 5% in heavy trading after being hit with two downgrades. The stock fell below a 69.10 buy point cleared Friday. Bank of America/Merrill Lynch cut the cleaning products maker to underperform from neutral, and UBS lowered shares to neutral from buy. The stock spiked 8% Friday after investor Carl Icahn disclosed a 9.1% stake.
Stocks opened sharply lower in strong trading Thursday, following overseas losses and mixed economic data.
The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq each dropped 0.6%. The Dow Jones industrial average backed off 0.4%. Volume jumped 36% on the NYSE and 4% on the Nasdaq, compared with the same time Wednesday.

Philadelphia Federal Reserve reported the slowdown in regional manufacturing eased notably in September, leaving its monthly survey at -1.9, its best reading since April. Analysts' consensus forecast was -4.0.
Leading economic indicators posted an unexpected slip in August, down 1.9%, the Conference Board reported. Economists had expected a flat reading. The gauge improved 0.4% in July.

Exxon Mobil (XOM) said it would pay $1.6 billion to buy leases to 196,000 acres in Montana's Bakken Shale formation from Denbury Resources (DNR). The deal, which also gives Denbury lease acreage in Wyoming and Texas, would raise Exxon's Bakken holdings to 600,000 acres. Denbury shares jumped 5% in opening trade. Exxon slipped a fraction.

ConAgra Foods (CAG) jumped 6% after topping fiscal first-quarter expectations by a wide margin. The company also raised its dividend and boosted its full-year earnings guidance. The gap-up put the stock just below its January high.

Leading stocks moved generally lower at the open, but Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) rose 11% in heavy trade. The drugmaker plummeted 48% Wednesday after insurer Aetna announced it would sharply curtail reimbursement for the company's blockbuster drug, Acthar. Shares remain at nine-month lows and well below critical levels of support.

On the downside, laser maker IPG Photonics (IPGP) dropped 3% in strong trade. Stocks shook off modest losses and turned slightly higher in morning trading Tuesday.The NYSE composite rose 0.3%, boosted by retailers and gold producers. The NYSE index had been down as much as 0.5%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq climbed 0.2%, while the Dow and S&P 500 edged up 0.1% each. Turnover continued to track a bit lower across the board.Tata Motors (TTM) revved up 3% to a new record high. The stock has gained 13% since clearing a 20.94 cup base buy point Aug. 11. Analysts see the India-based car maker's earnings surging 136% this year. Tata's 78 EPS Rank, which puts about a fifth of the market ahead of it in earnings growth, is off the pace of leadership.On the downside, Volcano (VOLC) gapped down and tumbled 10% in huge volume. Late Monday, the medical equipment maker said it's planning to offer $100 million in convertible senior notes. Volcano has a mediocre EPS Rank of 66.Impax Laboratories (IPXL) gapped down and dropped 6% on a downgrade. Jefferies cut the drugmaker to hold from buy and lowered its price target to $17 from $20. Impax eased after finding support at its 50-day moving average. It has a 78 EPS Rank.IPG Photonics (IPGP) fell 3%, pulling back from a four-session advance. Despite the retreat, the stock still sits 20% past a 19.30 buy point from a cup base. The company makes lasers used in materials processing. Analysts see it making 77 cents this year. It made 12 cents a share in 2009.Elsewhere, gold continued to push into new-high ground. The December contract climbed $21.90 to $1,269 an ounce.

Stocks rose modestly Friday, giving the S&P 500 its biggest weekly gain in more than a year. Volume, though, was less impressive. The S&P 500 moved up 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. The Nasdaq, weighed somewhat by Apple's (AAPL) 3% drop, added just a fraction. Volume fell on both major exchanges, according to preliminary data. For…

Stocks ended mixed near multiyear highs today as investors weighed improved U.S. jobs data against fresh economic troubles in Europe and Japan. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each rose 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today was higher on both major exchanges, according to preliminary data. The S&P is closing in…

Stocks opened tightly mixed Wednesday, as trading restarted after Superstorm Sandy forced a two-day market closure. The Dow Jones industrial average led, rising 0.4%. The S&P 500 gained 0.2% but the Nasdaq fell 0.3%, weighed in part by Baidu's (BIDU) 4% slump. Volume dipped a fraction on the Nasdaq and jumped 35% on the NYSE compared with the same time…

Stocks slid in light trading early Monday, as the dollar rose and Midwest manufacturing data was weaker than expected in October.The S&P 500 backed off 1.2%, the Nasdaq 1.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1%. Volume was sharply lower on both major exchanges.Chicago-region manufacturing slowed in October, sending the Chicago Purchasing Manager's index to 58.4, vs. a 60.4 reading for September. Analysts had forecast 58.9.Some Chinese tech stocks were under pressure, led by  Changyou.com's (CYOU) 15% drop. The online games provider's third-quarter sales and earnings beat the consensus expectations, and it offered in-line guidance for the fourth quarter.Sohu.com (SOHU) fell 9%. It topped expectations for both sales and earnings for the third quarter. Gross margins narrowed for a fifth straight quarter, although they were still a healthy 71%.A number of leading stocks were also under pressure, with IPG Photonics (IPGP), Watson Pharmaceuticals  (WPI) and ASML Holding (ASML) among the top stocks to slip 3% or more in early trade.

Zoll Medical (ZOLL) is on a roll. The stock zoomed to a record high Friday in reaction to its stellar fiscal second-quarter results delivered late Thursday. The maker of cardiac resuscitation products trounced views as earnings jumped 59% to 27 cents a share. Analysts were expecting 20 cents a share. In January, Zoll reported lower-than-expected sales, but this time it…

Stocks perked up shortly after results from a bond auction. The government auctioned off $21 billion in 10-year notes, fetching a yield of 3.34%. On Tuesday, the 10-year-yield jumped to 3.14%.The Nasdaq was up 0.3% and the S&P 500 0.2%. The Dow and NYSE composite turned fractionally higher. Turnover continued to track lower across the board.InterDigital (IDCC) climbed 5% to its best level since March 2000. The stock cleared a 36.91 buy point in a square-box base. InterDigital makes modems and chips used in notebook computers, mobile phones and other devices. Last month, the company topped views with a 14% rise in Q3 earnings and gave an upbeat Q4 sales outlook.Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrances (ULTA) erased earlier losses and rose 2% in fast trade. It's on pace to snap a four-session losing streak. But the stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has weakened to a C- from an A- several sessions ago. Ulta Salon cleared a 33.60 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern Nov. 24.On the downside, G-III Apparel (GIII) fell 3% in wild trading. The stock had been down nearly 8%, but it cut losses after finding support near its 50-day moving average. Before the open, the maker of Calvin Klein and Kenneth Cole clothing and accessories beat views with a 16% rise in Q3 earnings. Sales rose 24%, meeting views. G-III boosted its full-year profit outlook to $2.73-$2.83 a share vs. views for $2.69.Deere & Co.(DE) was off its session low but still down just over 1% in heavy trading. The stock briefly fell below a 79.76 buy point from a square-box base cleared Tuesday.Elsewhere, gold producers fell as gold tumbled $26.10 to settle at $1,382.90 an ounce. Allied Nevada Gold (ANV) dropped 6% and Agnico-Eagle Mines (AEM) lost 2%.

Stocks faded some more and have turned mixed in early afternoon trading Thursday.The Dow rose 0.2%, down from 0.9% at session peak. The S&P 500 turned flat. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite fell 0.3% and Nasdaq 0.1%. Turnover was again mixed with NYSE tracking lower and Nasdaq higher.China Yuchai International (CYD) bolted 8% to a six-year high. There's no news, but the stock has already traded more than twice its average daily volume. The company makes diesel engines for trucks and buses. China Yuchai's earnings growth accelerated in the past three quarters.Fossil (FOSL) rose 3% to a new record high. That puts the stock 36% past a 41.17 handle buy point. It has yet to test its 10-week line following its Aug. 5 breakout.On the downside, recent IPO China New Borun (BORN) reversed opening gains and dived 16% in big volume. A Seeking Alpha article criticized the Chinese alcohol producer.Children's Place (PLCE) gapped below its 50-day moving average and tumbled 15% after cutting its Q3 profit forecast. Citing weak fall sales, the retailer now expects earnings between $1.10 and $1.13 a share, down from a prior outlook of $1.38 to $1.43 a share. Currently, analysts are expecting $1.42 a share. Sterne Agee cut the stock to neutral from buy. Children's Place came close to potential support at its 200-day moving average.Caterpillar (CAT) reversed lower after hitting a two-year high on strong earnings. Cash America (CSH) and UPS (UPS) also turned lower.
Major stock indexes weakened after being rejected near the flat line.

The Nasdaq was down 0.4%, still better than the 1% deficit at session lows. The S&P 500 also dipped 0.4%, while the Dow and NYSE composite gave up 0.3% each. Turnover was mixed, tracking slightly higher on the Nasdaq and a tad lower on the NYSE.

AutoZone (AZO) gapped down and fell 3% on a downgrade. Citing valuation, Citigroup cut the auto parts retailer to hold from buy. Despite the drop, the stock is still about 4% past a 198.32 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

BioMarin Pharmaceutical (BMRN) trimmed a nearly 6% loss to just over 2%. Late Monday, the biotech posted an unexpected Q2 loss and lowered its full-year sales outlook. It's also stopping an experimental treatment for a rare form of muscular dystrophy due to disappointing early-stage trial results.

Research In Motion (RIMM) erased earlier gains and slipped 1% after unveiling its newest touch-screen smart phone, the BlackBerry Torch. The new device will be available Aug. 12 with prices starting at $199. It's the company's first phone to feature both a full touch-screen and the BlackBerry keyboard. Rival Apple (AAPL) eased a fraction.

On the upside, IPG Photonics (IPGP) gapped up and jumped 13% in heavy trading. It neared a 19.30 buy point from a cup base. Before the open, the maker of materials processing equipment blew past views with Q2 earnings of 22 cents a share. Analysts had expected 13 cents. Sales surged 67%, also above views. The firm pegged Q3 profit and revenue above views. IPG also announced the settlement of a patent dispute.

Quaker Chemical (KWR) shook off earlier losses and climbed 3% to a record high. On Monday, the stock cleared a 36.59 buy point from a cup base in more than twice its average volume. Earnings reports were center stage as stocks opened higher in light trade Wednesday.The S&P 500 rose 1.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average 1.3% and the Nasdaq 0.8%.Bank of America (BAC) led the Dow, rebounding 4% following a two-day dive. EOG Resources (EOG) posted the S&P 500's biggest gain, up 9%, after easily clearing third-quarter expectations.U.S employers added 110,00 jobs in October, fewer than September's 116,000 new jobs but better than forecasts for a 100,000 job gain, according to a private estimate. The ADP National Employment Report noted it was the 20th straight month of moderate job gains in the services side of the private sector. Employment in the goods producing sector declined by 4,000 jobs in October, while the manufacturing sector lost 8,000 jobs.MasterCard (MA) charged up 8% after topping analyst earnings and sales forecasts for the third quarter. The credit card payment processor reported EPS 43% higher vs. analyst forecasts for a 22% gain. Operating margins expanded to 55.1%, vs. 53.6% a year ago.The move lifted shares just past a 362.04 buy point on a six-week cup-without-handle base.IPG Photonics (IPGP) flashed ahead 8% in huge grade on strong third-quarter results. The industrial laser maker saw EPS gain 136% and revenue jump 62%, both better than expected. Company management noted uncertain conditions in the global economy, but said IPG benefitted from fiber optic lasers taking market share from the traditional carbon dioxide designs.The stock is working to hold support above its 10-week moving average, after correcting 48% from June to October.On the downside, Thoratec (THOR) dropped 12% after topping earnings expectations but falling short on revenue performance in the third quarter. The maker of implantable heart pumps had broken out of a double bottom Oct. 14. It is now more than 10% below its 34.95 buy point.

Stocks turned decisively negative in midday trade Thursday after a mixed start. The Nasdaq slid 1%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average trimmed 0.4% and 0.3% respectively. Volume rose across the board. Most blue chips were down. Chipmaker Intel (INTC) attracted the most volume. Intel fell 3% in twice its usual trade. On Wednesday, Intel gapped…
Monday drifted to a quiet start as stocks posted narrow early losses in weak volume.
The Nasdaq slipped 0.3% and the S&P 500 fell 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average held to an 0.1% decline. Volume opened down 47% on the Nasdaq and 16% lower on the NYSE.

Investors received few clear early signals on the stock market today. The sole piece of U.S. economic news, the Federal Reserve's Labor Market Conditions index, came in with a positive 1.3 reading for May — better than April's negative 1.9 showing but well below the consensus estimate for an increase to 2.3.

Overseas, China reported Sunday that its imports dropped sharply while export declines slowed in May. The report was widely seen as showing weak domestic demand and investment. China's markets speculated that it meant more central bank stimulus measures ahead.
Oil prices slipped more than 1% Monday after last week's pullback, in which U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude lost 1.9% and Europe's Brent crude fell 3.4%.
Energy stocks remained largely resilient, with U.S. drilling contractors posting some of the market's best early gains.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) led automakers higher, jumping 2% after a report from Robert W. Baird said that the stock had more room to run and raised its price target to 335 from 275. The gain lifted shares just above a 252.97 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Casino owners were under pressure, with Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dropping 5% apiece. Both stocks had surged last week after Las Vegas Sands CEO and Chairman Sheldon Adelson reportedly said that his company was pondering a takeover of Wynn Resorts. Adelson said that Wynn operated in two of Las Vegas Sands' biggest markets but that a takeover was "only a remote thought." Both stocks have been in decline since March 2014.

According to VeriSign Inc.’s (VRSN  -  Free Report) latest “The Domain Name Industry Brief”, domain name registrations decreased 0.4% sequentially to approximately 330.7 million across top-level domains (TLDs) at the end of the third quarter. Domain name registrations increased 3.7 million or 1.1% year over year.Country Code Top-Level Domains (“ccTLDs”) increased 3.2% year over year and 0.3% sequentially to 144.7 million in the September quarter. On a combined basis, .com and .net domain names increased 1.2% year over year to approximately 145.8 million in the third quarter.The company is benefiting from strong gTLD prospects. New gTLDs (“ngTLD”) represent 6.4% of total domain name registrations.Reportedly, new .com and .net registrations were 8.9 million compared with 8.3 million in the year-ago quarter, driven by strong demand in the United States. VeriSign reported that .com continued to maintain its position as the largest TLD, followed by .cn (China) and .tk (Tokelau).Shares of VeriSign have gained 45.6% year to date, significantly outperforming the 41.5% rally of the industry it belongs to.Domain Registration ProspectsVeriSign is the exclusive registrar of the .com, .net and .name domains per its agreements with The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN).The company announced a new agreement with ICANN per which the annual fee for a .net domain name registration will be increased from $8.20 to $9.02 effective Feb. 1, 2018. However, the other terms of the agreement remain unchanged.On the last conference call, VeriSign provided a raised guidance for its domain name base growth rate for 2017. The company now anticipates the same to grow in the range of 2.8% to 3.1%, up from its earlier forecast of 2% to 2.75%. Going ahead, for the fourth quarter, VeriSign projects domain name base registration to increase in the range of 0.4 million to 0.9 million.Also, gTLD prospects, international expansion through IDNs and investments in intellectual properties will boost results in our view. The company continues to benefit from strong demand in the United States as well as in international markets. Rise in bitcoin and cryptocurrency trading is also contributing to an increase in domain name registrations, which is a tailwind for the company.However, a significant headwind for VeriSign is the soft growth in active domain name business for .com and .net TLDs.Also, the negative impact of search engine adjustments on domain monetization and increasing operating expenses related to sales and marketing remain headwinds.VeriSign, Inc. Revenue (TTM) VeriSign, Inc. Revenue (TTM) | VeriSign, Inc. Prominent names like Airbus and Koninklijke Philips N.V. are part of its clientele.The company’s strategic partnerships with Schneider Electric, The Boeing Co., Ford Motor Co., Siemens, Boom Supersonic and United Launch Alliance have expanded its geographic reach and market penetration. Additionally, the ISO 9001: 2008-certification for its products is a testament of the improving quality of its productsStratasys’  bottom line in the third quarter improved significantly  year over year. The company’s constant focus on a stringent cost  structure aids growth.Considering the evolving nature of the 3D printing market and the high cost of operations associated with it, we believe that much of the company’s long-term profitability will depend on efficient cost management.Stratasys, Ltd. After two years of negotiations, Alphabet Inc.’s (GOOGL  -  Free Report) online video streaming platform, YouTube finally signed agreements with Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group for publishing their music on the platform in exchange of royalties.The duration of the contracts with both music labels is still unknown. Back in May, the platform had inked a similar kind of deal with Warner Music Group.The deals come after record labels’ repeated complaints to YouTube for providing insufficient compensation to artists and ignoring copyright breach. Deals like these are expected to help strengthen the company’s relationships with leading record labels.Notably, shares of Alphabet have gained 36.3% year to date, outperforming the 28.3% rally of the industry it belongs to.New Music ServiceYouTube intends to convert its free users to monthly subscribers. The long-term deals will help Alphabet to introduce a new paid music service, which is likely to be launched early next year. According to reports, the service is being internally referred to as Remix but it is still unclear if the company will retain it.Its music streaming service could be unique as it will allow subscribers to access live concert footage, exclusive music videos and karaoke tracks.Our TakeOnline and mobile video consumption is rising and YouTube is strongly positioned to benefit from the trend. It is widely used for consuming music and is one of the most important platforms for record labels to promote their albums. The U.S. music industry witnessed 15% growth in the first half of 2017, according to the Recording Industry Association of America, while global sales grew 5.9%, according to the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry. This bodes well for the platform.Recently, the YouTube Red subscription service was rolled out for those interested in ad-free, offline, or background listening. Programs like Google Preferred, Content ID, TrueView ads indicate that Alphabet is making efforts to maintain its revenue growth trend. Also, the company is working on YouTube Originals, the prospects of which look promising.Alphabet Inc. Revenue (TTM) Alphabet Inc. Revenue (TTM) | Alphabet Inc. Facebook Inc. (FB  -  Free Report) announced a number of initiatives in its attempts to build a safer community.In its latest blog post, Facebook revealed that “engagement bait” posts that forcibly seek an individual’s attention by provoking them to like, share or comment will be demoted by the company.The social media giant also unveiled tools to prevent harassment on the platform as well as on Messenger by preventing friend requests and messages from a separate account of a user who has already been blocked.Facebook is also coming down heavily on fake accounts by using signals like the IP address of the user.Facebook also rolled out changes to tackle unwanted conversations on Messenger. Per the company, once the conversation is ignored by the reader, notifications will be disabled and it will subsequently be moved to Filtered Messages Folder. The sender will not be intimated whether the message has been read, thus eliminating any chance of abuse outside the platform.Facebook also unveiled an advanced version of its face recognition technology to help users identify pictures in which they are not tagged as well as help them detect when others use their images as profile picture.  Facebook’s aim as reported by the company is “to reduce the spread of content that is spammy, sensational, or misleading in order to promote more meaningful and authentic conversations on Facebook.”We believe these initiatives will significantly drive Facebook’s user base and sustain the share price momentum. Notably, Facebook has gained 50.8% year to date, substantially outperforming the industry’s 24.6% rally.Developing Social InfrastructureFacebook is considered to have pioneered the concept of social networking, which is why it enjoys a first mover’s advantage in this market. The company’s user base continues to grow at a significant pace driven by new features and tools that improve engagement.Facebook’s continuous efforts clearly indicate that the company is on track to accomplish its mission to protect the community.In February, CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced in his statement, “the most important thing we at Facebook can do is develop the social infrastructure to give people the power to build a global community that works for all of us.”We note that rising abuse on social media is a serious concern these days. Cyber bullying and trolling are a serious threat to user growth on social networking platforms.Facebook’s initiatives to declutter News Feed, which is the first thing the user views after logging on the platform, and provide more security to users will help drive user satisfaction in our view.The company’s emphasis to drive user engagement by making the platform safer to use is expected to be accretive to its growth. The latest developments to make the platform more viable are encouraging.Facebook, Inc. Revenue (TTM) Facebook, Inc. Revenue (TTM) | Facebook, Inc. FactSet Research Systems Inc. (FDS  -  Free Report) reported mixed results for fiscal first-quarter 2018. While earnings came ahead of the Zacks Consensus Estimate, revenues missed the same. However, on a year-over-year basis, it registered growth on both the counts.The company reported adjusted earnings per share of $2.04, which surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.98. The figure exceeded the guided range of $1.93 to $1.99 per share. Moreover, adjusted earnings improved 16.6% on a year-over-year basis.Quarter DetailsFactSet’s revenues of $329.1 million increased 14.3% from the year-ago quarter and came ahead of the guided range of $321 million-$328 million. Organic revenues increased 5.8% year over year to $304.3 million during the quarter. Successful integration of newly acquired businesses along with expansion in workflow-based solutions backed the company’s top-line performance. However, the figure missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $331 million.In the reported quarter, FactSet’s revenues from the United States increased to $208.8 million while international revenues grew to $120.4 million. Excluding the impact of foreign currency, acquisitions and disposition, U.S. revenues and international revenues rose 4.8% and 7.7%, respectively, on a year-over-year basis.FactSet Research Systems Inc. Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise FactSet Research Systems Inc. Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise | FactSet Research Systems Inc. QuoteThe company’s Annual Subscription Value (ASV) increased to $1.32 billion as of Nov 30, 2017, up 12.8% from the year-ago quarter figure of $1.17 billion. Of this, nearly 84.2% was generated by buy-side clients while the rest came from sell-side firms performing functions like mergers & acquisition, advisory work and equity research. Organically, it had increased 5.1% on a year-over-year basis.FactSet added 65 clients in the reported quarter, taking the tally to 4,809. The company retained 90% of its clients. The percentage of client retention was more than 95% of ASV.Coming to the operational metrics, FactSet reported a 21% rise in total operating expenses. As a percentage of revenues, operating expenses increased approximately 400 basis points (bps) to 73%.FactSet’s adjusted operating income increased 10.6% from the year-ago quarter to $105.1 million. However, operating margin decreased 130 bps year over year to 31.7%, owing to increased operating expenses as a percentage of revenues.Adjusted net income during the quarter was $80.9 million compared with $70.1 million in the year-ago quarter.FactSet exited the quarter with $221.9 million in cash and cash equivalents, compared with $194.7 million from the previous quarter. Long-term debt at the end of the quarter amounted to $574.7 million.Cash flow from operations during the quarter was $61.1 million. The company generated free cash flow of $55.2 million.FactSet repurchased $30.9 million worth of its common stock under its existing share repurchase authorization during the first quarter. The company has still $213.2 million remaining under the share repurchase authorization as of Nov 30, 2017.GuidanceStarting this quarter, the company has decided not to provide quarterly guidance. Instead, it will issue a fiscal guidance. The company initiated guidance for fiscal 2018. GAAP revenues are expected to be between $1.34 billion and $1.36 billion (mid-point $1.35 billion). The Zacks Consensus Estimate is currently pegged at $1.36 billion.Organic ASV for fiscal 2018 is projected to increase by $65 million to $85 million, representing year-over-year growth of 4.9% to 6.5%. The anticipated range for adjusted operating margin is 31% and 32.5%.Adjusted earnings are expected to be within $8.25 and $8.45 (mid-point $8.35). The midpoint represents 14% year-over-year growth. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $8.18 per share.Bottom LineShares of Factset have gained 25.3% year to date, underperforming the industry’s 30.7% rally. Investors seem concern about lower-than-expected revenues and unimpressive top-line guidance for fiscal 2018. Furthermore, declining client retention ratio remains a major concern. The company’s client retention ratio in the first quarter came in at 90%, tanking 300 basis points (bps) from the year-ago quarter and 100 bps from the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017. It should be noted that a strong client retention ratio signifies more stable revenues.Although the company continues to add clients every quarter, it has failed to retain old clients. This will negatively impact its near-term top-line growth.Zacks Rank and Stocks to ConsiderFactset has a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell).Some of the better-ranked stocks in the broader technology sector are Intel Corporation (INTC  -  Free Report), NetApp, Inc. (NTAP  -  Free Report) and IPG Photonics Corporation (IPGP  -  Free Report), all sporting a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). IPG Photonics Corporation (IPGP  -  Free Report) has been struggling lately, but the selling pressure may be coming to an end soon. That is because IPGP recently saw a Hammer Chart Pattern which can signal that the stock is nearing a bottom.What is a Hammer Chart Pattern? A hammer chart pattern is a popular technical indicator that is used in candlestick charting. The hammer appears when a stock tumbles during the day, but then finds strength at some point in the session to close near or above its opening price. This forms a candlestick that resembles a hammer, and it can suggest that the market has found a low point in the stock, and that better days are ahead.Other FactorsPlus, earnings estimates have been rising for this company, even despite the sluggish trading lately. In just the past 60 days alone 3 estimates have gone higher, compared to none lower, while the consensus estimate has also moved in the right direction.Estimates have actually risen so much that the stock now has a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) suggesting this relatively unloved stock could be due for a breakout soon. This will be especially true if IPGP stock can build momentum from here and find a way to continue higher of off this encouraging trading development.
